{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{short description|Investigations into fraud Thai government officers and temples}} [[File:พระวิหาร วัดสระเกศ.jpg|thumb|275px|[[Wat Saket]], Buddhist temple in [[Bangkok]]]]
The '''2017–18 Thai temple fraud investigations''' ({{lang-th|คดีเงินทอนวัด|translit=Kadi nguen thon wat|lit=Case of change of money by temples}}) were a series of investigations by the [[NCPO|Thai junta]] of the alleged abuse of governmental subsidies by government officers and Buddhist temples. The investigations started in 2017, and culminated in the controversial May 2018 arrest of five monks with leading positions in the Thai [[sangha|monastic community]]. The investigations have been described as unprecedented and as a critical blow to the faith of Thai Buddhist devotees. They have been subject to criticism and political speculation. In July 2018, the crisis was cited by the junta to amend laws, with the result that the monastic community could no longer choose their own [[Supreme Sangha Council|leading council members]], but these were to be chosen by the [[King of Thailand|Thai King]], and possibly the ruling [[NCPO]].
== Background == In Thailand, [[wat|Thai temples]] ({{lang-th|วัด}}; {{rtgs|''wat''}}) do not receive regular financial support from the government, but can make budget requests from the government for restoration or maintenance of temples, educational activities, or other activities for the "dissemination of Buddhism". This is done through the [[National Office of Buddhism]] (NOB), a government department.<ref name="TNN 2017-06-09" />
Since 2015, the Counter Corruption Division and the {{ill|State Audit Office|th|สำนักงานการตรวจเงินแผ่นดิน}}, both governmental departments, had been receiving reports about fraud with temple budget committed by government officials. The Counter Corruption Division, which would normally report this to the police, could find little evidence. Furthermore, the NOB gave little information.<ref name="Nation 2017-07-03" /> This changed when, in February 2017, former policeman Pongporn Pramsaneh was appointed head of the NOB by the [[National Council for Peace and Order]] (NCPO).<ref name="Nation 2017-07-03" /><ref name="Dubus">{{cite news |last1=Dubus |first1=Arnaud |title=Thai junta hounds senior monks but denies internal graft |url=https://www.ucanews.com/news/thai-junta-hounds-senior-monks-but-denies-internal-graft/82502 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727155437/https://www.ucanews.com/news/thai-junta-hounds-senior-monks-but-denies-internal-graft/82502 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[Union of Catholic Asian News]] |date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
== First two investigations (August 2017) == [[File:Watpailom 02.jpg|thumb|Thai monks walking to receive [[alms#Buddhism|alms]]]]
The case started in August 2017<ref name="Lok Wannee">{{cite news|title=“สุวพันธุ์”ขอทุกฝ่ายมั่นใจดำเนินคดีเงินทอนวัดยุติธรรม|trans-title=Suwapan asks everyone to be confident that the lawsuits for temple fraud will be handled with justice|url=http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=304278 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727155937/http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=304278 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=Lok Wannee|date=19 April 2018|language=th}}</ref> when Phrakhru Baitika Anand Khemanando, abbot of a temple in [[Phetchaburi Province]], complained about NOB civil servants. He had requested a budget of eleven million [[Thai baht|baht]], which was granted, but the government officer involved asked the abbot to return ten million baht to him. Khemanando made his complaint to the Counter Corruption Division and the State Audit Office. The Counter Corruption Division investigated the matter further. The commission investigated ten sites throughout Thailand and searched the houses of high-ranking officers of the NOB. The main focus was the use of budgets from 2012 to 2016 that were meant for restoration and repair of temples.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26">{{cite news|title=ย้อนรอยคดีเงินทอนวัดสะเทือนวงการสงฆ์|trans-title=Looking back at the temple fraud case that shocked the Saṅgha |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8yxy4BwXad0|accessdate=26 May 2018|work=[[Thai Rath]]|date=24 May 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref name="Thai PBS">{{cite news |title=ย้อนรอย ทุจริต 40 วัดดังทั่วไทย |trans-title=Temple fraud in retrospect: 40 temples all over Thailand |url=https://news.thaipbs.or.th/content/272401 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727155943/https://news.thaipbs.or.th/content/272401 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[Thai PBS]] |date=24 May 2018 |language=th}}</ref>
The commission stated that 33 temples had requested and received subsidies from the NOB, but ten government officials had asked twelve of these temples to return 75 percent of the obtained funds, illegally.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" /> The loss of budget was estimated at 60 million baht.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" /> Four civilians and one monk were accused of conspiring with government officials.<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" />
Later, a second investigation was held, in cooperation with another six government departments:<ref name="Nation 2017-07-03">{{cite news |title=ทุจริต "เงินทอนวัด" สะเทือนวงการสงฆ์ |trans-title=Fraud with changing money shocked the Saṅgha |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZogJklgIOuc |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Nation TV (Thailand)|Nation TV]] |date=3 July 2017|format=Video|language=th}}</ref>[[File:Phaya Thai Road AMLO IMG 7021.jpg|thumb|The [[Anti-Money Laundering Office (Thailand)|Anti-Money Laundering Office]] helped to investigate fraud in the [[National Office of Buddhism|NOB]].|alt=Tall skyscraper behind elevated highway]] * the [[Anti-Money Laundering Office (Thailand)|Anti-Money Laundering Office]]; * the {{ill|Office of Public Sector Anti-Corruption Commission|th|สำนักงานคณะกรรมการป้องกันและปราบปรามการทุจริตในภาครัฐ}}; * the [[National Anti-Corruption Commission (Thailand)|National Anti-Corruption Commission]] (NACP; another department than the Counter Corruption Division); * the [[Department of Special Investigation]]; * the State Audit Office; and * the [[Royal Thai Police]].<ref name="Nation 2017-07-03" /><ref>{{cite news |title='แชร์ลูกโซ่-เงินทอนวัด' เครือข่ายแบ่งผลประโยชน์พระชั้นผู้ใหญ่ |trans-title=Pyramid structure in temple fraud: network of shared interests of senior monks |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M75LBmorbKQ |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=10 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref>
Inspectors discovered the same pattern in another 23 temples, with one temple losing 31 million baht in this manner. This time, the same ten officers were charged, plus another three officers, all from the NOB.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="Thai PBS" /><ref name="TNN24 2017-09-30">{{cite news |title=เงินทอนวัดล็อต 2 พระร่วมทำผิด - ทุจริตต่อเนื่อง |trans-title=Second temple fraud: monks joined in, continuous fraud |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YUugx5RFFAQ |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=30 September 2017 |language=th}}</ref> The highest-ranking officers were two former NOB directors: Panom Sornsilp and Nopparat Benjawatthanan.<ref name="TNN24 2017-09-30" /><ref name="Straight">{{cite news |last1=Thongnoi |first1=Jitsiree |title=More arrests likely in Thai crackdown on errant monks |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/more-arrests-likely-in-thai-crackdown-on-errant-monks |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727155950/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/more-arrests-likely-in-thai-crackdown-on-errant-monks |archive-date=27 July 2018 | dead-url=no |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=1 June 2018}}</ref> A high-ranking soldier, who had been deployed without contract as a bodyguard at the State Audit Office, was also implicated.<ref>{{cite news|title=บก.ทัพไทยสั่งสำรองราชการ “ร.ท.ฐิติทัศน์” <!--left untranslated per [[WP:CRIME]]-->|url=http://www.tnamcot.com/view/5affa78ae3f8e4f60185a2f1 |archive-url=https://perma.cc/D5YT-FVWD?type=image |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[Thai News Agency]]|publisher=[[MCOT]]|date=19 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> Temples in [[Ayutthaya (city)|Ayutthaya]], [[Songkhla]], [[Lopburi]], and Bangkok were investigated,<ref name="TNN24 2017-09-30" /><ref>{{cite news|title=ปปช.เล็งชี้มูลคดีทุจริตเงินทอนวัดสงขลาวันที่ 8 ม.ค. |trans-title=NACP concludes evidence temple fraud in Songkhla on 8 January |url=http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=293368 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727160005/http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=293368 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=Lok Wannee|date=5 January 2018|language=th}}</ref> and it was reported that the officers conspired with four monks and two other civilians. The loss was assessed at 140 to 141 million baht.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="TNN24 2017-09-30" /><ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" /> As a result, four monks from [[Petchabun]], Lopburi, and Bangkok were arrested.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|last1=Niyomyat|first1=Aukkarapon|last2=Wongcha-um|first2=Panu|title=Thailand reinstates chief of national Buddhism office|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/thailand-buddhism/thailand-reinstates-chief-of-national-buddhism-office-idUSL4N1M73P5 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727160107/https://www.reuters.com/article/thailand-buddhism/thailand-reinstates-chief-of-national-buddhism-office-idUSL4N1M73P5 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|agency=[[Reuters]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=พระครูทุจริตเงินทอนวัดกลับไทย-แต่หาตัวไม่พบ |trans-title=Phra Khru accused of temple fraud returns to Thailand, but can't be found |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIWul5ocpqw |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=24 September 2017 |language=th}}</ref> At least one monk was later released on a bail of 1.5 million baht.<ref>{{cite news|title=ศาลให้ประกัน “พระครูกิตติฯ” คดีสมคบฟอกเงินทอนวัด 28 ล้าน <!--left untranslated per [[WP:CRIME]]-->|url=http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=298981 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727161233/http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=298981 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[Lok Wannee]]|language=th}}</ref>
Criticism of the NOB grew quickly, as its director Pongporn came under attack. He was seen to vilify Buddhist monks. Under pressure of pro-Buddhist organizations such as the Thailand Buddhists Federation, he was temporarily removed from his position in August 2017,<ref name="Reuters 17-08-29">{{cite news|last1=Tanakasempipat|first1=Patpicha|title=Thailand's Buddhism chief removed after pressure from religious groups|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-buddhism/thailands-buddhism-chief-removed-after-pressure-from-religious-groups-idUSKCN1B91FE |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727161237/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-buddhism/thailands-buddhism-chief-removed-after-pressure-from-religious-groups-idUSKCN1B91FE |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |date=29 August 2017|accessdate=27 May 2018|agency=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> only to be re-appointed one month later.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="Reuters" />
On 18 July 2018, another monk in the second investigation was summoned, accused of illegally transferring government funds to another temple, not his own. This monk had a leading position in Wat Phichaiyat. {{As of|2018|7|19|post=,}} the monk was still at large.<ref>{{cite news |title=ออกหมายเรียก "พระราชรัตนมุนี" ฟอกเงินคดีทุจริตเงินทอนวัด <!--title left untranslated per [[WP:CRIME]]-->|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w2vEWSzsssQ |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=[[PPTV (Thailand)|PPTV]]|format=Video|date=18 July 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=ไร้เงา เจ้าคุณบุญเทียม หลังกองปราบออกหมายเรียก <!--title left untranslated per [[WP:CRIME]]-->|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PeGcUQEk63A |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=[[Channel 8 (Thailand)|Channel 8]]|format=Video|date=19 July 2018 |language=th}}</ref>
== Third investigation (January 2018) == [[File:ตราสัญลักษณ์ ปปช.jpg|thumb|Logo of the [[National Anti-Corruption Commission (Thailand)|National Anti-Corruption Commission]]|upright=0.7]]
After his re-appointment, Pongporn started a third investigation of illegal dealings, and reported that another ten temples had had their budget cut off in the same manner as the temples in the second investigation. Pongporn revealed the names of only three temples, however. He further stated that the officers held responsible were the same suspects as before, who worked together in a network. Apart from problems with returning budget, another problem was found concerning eight monks from three temples:<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="Thai PBS" /><ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" />
* {{ill|Phra Prom Dilok|th|พระพรหมดิลก}}, a member of the [[Supreme Sangha Council]], {{ill|monastic head|th|เจ้าคณะภาค}} of the Bangkok Region and abbot of {{ill|Wat Sam Phraya|th|วัดสามพระยา}}; * {{ill|Phra Prom Methee|th|พระพรหมเมธี}}, also a member of the Sangha Council and head of the upper central and northern ecclesiastical regions, abbot of {{ill|Wat Samphantawong|th|วัดสัมพันธวงศารามวรวิหาร}}; * {{ill|Phra Prom Sitthi|th|พระพรหมสิทธิ}}, also a member and head of some northeastern regions, abbot of [[Wat Saket]]; * another four monks who were assistant-abbots of Wat Saket;<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3">{{cite news |title=เปิดตัวละครทุจริตเงินทอนวัด-ฉาววงการสงฆ์ |trans-title=Taking a look at people involved in temple fraud, Saṅgha scandals |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f4IMIllxIe0 |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=3 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref name="Ngamkham" /> * another monk who was a secretary to Phra Prom Dilok.<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" /> * In some news reports, another four unnamed accused monks are listed.<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" />
These eight monks were accused of using the funds provided for purposes other than initially requested. The government funding was spent on Buddhist projects, but for projects which had already been funded. The funds were not spent on the projects for which the budget was initially requested. In these cases, no money was withheld, though civil servants had withheld money in other, legitimate budget requests from the three temples. As the investigations continued, they were split into two task forces: the NOB continued its internal investigation and the National Anti-Corruption Commission cooperated with the Counter Corruption Division to continue the investigations of parties not part of the NOB.<ref name="Lok Wannee" /><ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /> Pongporn made a press statement saying that a commission would be established in the NOB to deal with the suspects.<ref>{{cite news|title=พศ.เตรียมตั้งคกก.ลงโทษวินัย9ขรก.เอี่ยวทุจริตเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=NOB prepares a commission to punish 9 officers involved in temple fraud |url=http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=293920 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727161247/http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=293920 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=Lok Wannee|date=10 January 2018|language=th}}</ref> Misappropriated funds to this point were estimated to be 169 million baht.<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" />
=== Arrests (May 2018) === [[File:BAMF-Ablehnung.JPG|thumb|Example letter of response to an asylum request|alt=Letter in German language|upright=0.6]]
In May 2018, authorities charged three members of the Sangha Council with government budget fraud and money laundering,<ref>{{cite news|title=ศาลไม่ให้ประกัน5พระผู้ใหญ่คดีโกงเงินทอนวัด-จับสึกคุมส่งเรือนจำ |trans-title=Court refuses bail five senior monks in lawsuit temple fraud, defrocks and imprisons them |url=https://www.innnews.co.th/breaking-news/news_94224/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727162005/https://www.innnews.co.th/breaking-news/news_94224/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |deadurl=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=INN|date=24 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> citing that money was found to be transferred to accounts of supporters of their temples.<ref>{{cite news|title=กองปราบบุก3จุด บ้านหรู-ร้านสังฆภัณฑ์ คุ้ยโอน5ล้านเอี่ยวเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=Crime Suppression invades 3 places, [including] villa and shop with monastic accessories, discovered 5 M related to temple fraud |url=http://www.bangkokbiznews.com/news/detail/802328 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727162028/http://www.bangkokbiznews.com/news/detail/802328 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=Bangkok Biz News|date=19 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> The police issued arrest warrants,<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /> and the monks were to be removed from the council on 30 May 2018.<ref name="Ngamkham" /> Preceding that decision, on 25 May, Phra Prom Dilok, as well as the three deputy abbots, were arrested, [[defrock]]ed, and held in custody.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Charuvastra|first1=Teeranai|title=Buddha Issara Arrested in Dawn Raid|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2018/05/24/buddha-issara-arrested-in-dawn-raid/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727162034/http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2018/05/24/buddha-issara-arrested-in-dawn-raid/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=26 May 2018|work=[[Khaosod English]]|publisher=Matichon Publishing|date=24 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="Benar">{{cite news|last1=Watcharasakwet|first1=Wilawan|title=Thai Police Arrest 5 Monks for Alleged Money Laundering|url=https://www.benarnews.org/english/news/thai/monks-charged-05242018162927.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727162041/https://www.benarnews.org/english/news/thai/monks-charged-05242018162927.html |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=26 May 2018|work=Benar News|date=24 May 2018}}</ref> (Thai law states that monks cannot be jailed, therefore any monk taken into custody must be [[defrock]]ed if denied release on bail, even before guilt is determined.)<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1472081/#cxrecs_s |archive-url=https://archive.today/20180727163211/https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1472081#cxrecs_s |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |title=Phra Buddha Isara disrobed, detained |work=[[Bangkok Post]] |date=24 May 2018 |access-date=26 May 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The detention was to last for twelve days.<ref name="Ngamkham" /> There were other monks who saw their budget cut off and who were accused of being involved in the scam, but some of them argued that they were misled by officials, who stated that the budget returned to them was to be used for other temples.<ref name="TR 2018-05-26" /><ref name="TNA" />
The arrests of the four monks accused of money fraud were combined with the arrest of {{ill|Phra Buddha Issara|th|พระพุทธะอิสระ}}, a hardline, ultra-royalist monk who had taken part in the [[2014 Thai coup d'état|2014 Thailand coup d'état]].<ref name="SMH" /> He was from a fourth temple called Wat Oh Noy. Many officials were surprised by this arrest, because Phra Buddha Issara was known to have close ties with the ruling junta<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2018/05/24/buddha-issara-accused-of-forging-royal-emblem/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727162116/http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2018/05/24/buddha-issara-accused-of-forging-royal-emblem/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |title=Buddha Issara Accused of Royal Forgery|date=24 May 2018 |work=Khaosod English |access-date=25 May 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/sex-drugs-and-embezzlement-no-big-deal-for-thailands-buddhist-monks/2015/04/28/9df1934e-dd2a-11e4-b6d7-b9bc8acf16f7_story.html |title=Thai Buddhist monk wants to clean up his country's religious institutions|last=Fifield|first=Anna|date=28 April 2015 |work=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=11 September 2017 }}</ref> and had encouraged Pongporn's investigations into fraud in the first place.<ref name="Reuters 17-08-29" /> The monk was arrested on charges brought against him in 2014, including alleged robbery and detaining officials. The most serious charge against him, filed in 2017, was [[Lèse majesté in Thailand|unauthorized use]] of the royal seal.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2018/05/24/buddha-issara-arrested-in-dawn-raid/|title=Buddha Issara Arrested in Dawn Raid|date=24 May 2018|work=Khaosod English |access-date=25 May 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-buddhism/thailand-arrests-senior-monks-in-temple-raids-to-clean-up-buddhism-idUSKCN1IP0X3 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727162201/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-buddhism/thailand-arrests-senior-monks-in-temple-raids-to-clean-up-buddhism-idUSKCN1IP0X3 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |title=Thailand arrests senior monks in temple raids to clean up Buddhism|agency=[[Reuters]] |access-date=25 May 2018}}</ref> Politician and activist {{ill|Paiboon Nititawan|th|ไพบูลย์_นิติตะวัน}} expressed surprise that this arrest happened at the same time as the arrest of the four monks, but argued that it was unrelated to it.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/news/crimecourtscalamity/calamity/2018/05/25/buddha-issara-followers-fume-at-defrocked-monks-arrest/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163154/http://www.khaosodenglish.com/news/crimecourtscalamity/calamity/2018/05/25/buddha-issara-followers-fume-at-defrocked-monks-arrest/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |title=Buddha Issara Followers Fume at Defrocked Monk's Arrest|date=25 May 2018|work=Khaosod English |access-date=26 May 2018 }}</ref> News commentator Chaturong Jong-asa argued that Thai authorities arrested the monks accused of fraud together with Phra Buddha Issara in order to please multiple political interest groups at the same time, without any group feeling left out.<ref name="Dubus" /><ref name="Jomquan" />
[[File:ThaiConCourt-Seal-002.jpg|thumb|Seal of the [[Constitutional Court of Thailand]]. The Buddhist Protection Center appealed to the court with regard to the 2018 arrests.|upright=0.7]]
The arrests were made simultaneously by raids of 100–200 commandos,<ref name="Ngamkham">{{cite news|last1=Ngamkham|first1=Wassayos|title=Senior monks defrocked after raids|work=Bangkok Post|date=25 May 2018 |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2147542/senior-thai-monks-arrested-embezzlement-and-robbery |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727161241/https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2147542/senior-thai-monks-arrested-embezzlement-and-robbery |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |via=[[South China Morning Post]] }}</ref><ref name="SMH">{{cite news|last1=Wongcha-um|first1=Panu|title=Thailand raids temples, arrest monks in fight to clean up Buddhism|url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/asia/thailand-raids-temples-arrest-monks-in-fight-to-clean-up-buddhism-20180525-p4zhhv.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163212/https://www.smh.com.au/world/asia/thailand-raids-temples-arrest-monks-in-fight-to-clean-up-buddhism-20180525-p4zhhv.html |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=26 May 2018|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=25 May 2018}}</ref> which was widely criticized as excessive force.<ref name="Dubus" /><ref>{{cite news |last1=Somjittranukit |first1=Kornkritch |title=From temple to prison: Implications of Buddha Issara's arrest |url=https://prachatai.com/english/node/7764 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163214/https://prachatai.com/english/node/7764 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Prachatai]]}}</ref> Despite these unannounced raids, Phra Prom Sitthi and Phra Prom Methee were not found.<ref name="Jomquan" /> The secretary of Phra Prom Dilok's temple was also taken into custody, totaling five monks. There were also four [[layperson]]s imprisoned and accused of cooperating in the alleged fraud,<ref name="Ngamkham" /><ref name="BEC 2018-05-24">{{cite news|title=บุกจับ 5 พระผู้ใหญ่วัดดัง กทม. เอี่ยวเงินทอนวัด เจ้าอาวาสวัดสระเกศล่องหน คาดหนีออกประตูลับ |trans-title=Invasive arrest 5 senior monks well-known Bangkok temples implicated in temple fraud, abbot Wat Saket at large, probably fled through secret doorway |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LTuspxuiodc|accessdate=26 May 2018|work=[[BEC-TERO]]|format=Video|date=24 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> who were volunteers or supporters of Phra Prom Sitthi's temple,<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" /> mostly connected with a media production company.<ref name="Perdpom">{{cite news |title=เหลี่ยมจีวรซ่อนเงินวัด |trans-title=Hiding the temple's money behind a monk's robe |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rya0lRfMqMg |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[Thai PBS]] |date=11 June 2018|format=Video|language=th}}</ref> One of these was the mother of the soldier accused earlier.<ref name="TNN24 2018-6-3" />
On 30 May, Phra Prom Sitthi turned himself in.<ref>{{cite news |title=สอบเครียด "พระพรหมสิทธิ" ปมเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=Intense questioning Phra Phrom Sitthi about temple fraud |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A8Ga4trVMhg |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Thai Rath]] |date=30 May 2018|format=Video|language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title='เจ้าคุณธงชัย' ถึงกองปราบแล้ว ตร.ปิดห้องเค้นสอบเครียด เงินทอนวัด |trans-title=Chao Khun Thongchai arrived at Crime Suppression Department, police closes down room to intensely question him about temple fraud |url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1295006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163221/https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1295006 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Thai Rath]] |language=th}}</ref> On 4 June, the Thai authorities reported that Phra Prom Methee had fled the country and was seeking [[asylum in Germany]]. Representatives of the Thai police went to Germany to demand Phra Prom Methee's return, but to no avail: German officials stated the asylum investigations had to be finished first, and only then could extradition be considered.<ref>{{cite news |title=Buddhist monk seeks asylum in Germany, says Thai report |url=http://www.dw.com/en/buddhist-monk-seeks-asylum-in-germany-says-thai-report/a-44076980 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163742/https://www.dw.com/en/buddhist-monk-seeks-asylum-in-germany-says-thai-report/a-44076980 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[Deutsche Welle]]| agency=Reuters, [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur ]], [[Agence France-Presse]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=ชัดเจนแล้ว นำตัว 'เจ้าคุณจำนงค์' ขึ้นศาลเยอรมนี ‘บิ๊กแป๊ะ’ เจรจาไม่สำเร็จ |trans-title=Confirmed: Chao Khun Chamnong is at German [asylum] court, Sanit fails to negotiate |url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1300256 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163745/https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1300256 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Thai Rath]] |date=5 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref> News outlet [[Matichon]] argued that the actions of the Thai police had possibly increased Phra Prom Methee's prospects for asylum, because it made the lawsuit look politically motivated.<ref>{{cite news |title='พระพรหมเมธี' ได้รับคุ้มครองในฐานะผู้ลี้ภัยแล้ว กบดานเยอรมนีอย่างน้อย 2 เดือน ปิดประตูส่งผู้ร้ายข้ามแดน |trans-title=Phra Prom Methee is protected as asylum seeker, will hide in Germany at least two months, no chance at extradition |url=https://www.matichon.co.th/local/crime/news_1003684 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163753/https://www.matichon.co.th/local/crime/news_1003684 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=[[Matichon]] |date=18 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref>
During their detention, the five former monks maintained certain monastic precepts, such as eating only two meals a day.<ref name="BEC 2018-05-26">{{cite news|title=ย้อนไทม์ไลน์ล้างบางขบวนการ 'อมเงินวัด' สะเทือนวงการสงฆ์!|trans-title= Review of [how] elimination siphoning money temples shocked the Saṅgha |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zGyp0xEp3C0|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[BEC-TERO]]|format=Video|date=26 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> On 31 May, the three monks who were members of the Saṅgha Council were officially removed from their positions.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thai king revokes ranks of senior monks |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/thai-king-revokes-ranks-of-senior-monks |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727163757/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/thai-king-revokes-ranks-of-senior-monks |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=The Straits Times|agency=Reuters|date=31 May 2018}}</ref> On 17 June, the Buddhist Protection Center, a network that [[Wat Paknam Bhasicharoen#Appointment as Supreme Patriarch stalled (2013–15)|had previously held nationwide protests by monks against the junta]], appealed to the [[Constitutional Court of Thailand|Thai Constitutional Court]], arguing that the forced defrocking of the monks without trial was unlawful and in violation of the [[Constitution of Thailand|Thai constitution]].<ref>{{cite news |title=ศูนย์พิทักษ์พระพุทธศาสนาฯ ปัดข่าวปลุกระดม 'พระ-เณร' แสดงพลังที่พุทธมณฑล |trans-title= Buddhist Protection Center denies news of mobilizing monks for protest at Phutthamonthon |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0d7D9OZyeEk |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=[[BEC-TERO]]|format=Video|date=17 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref>
== Fourth investigation (May 2018–present) == In the same period that the arrests of the four prominent monks took place, the Counter Corruption Division and the National Office of Buddhism started a fourth investigation. This one involved the use of government funds by temples in the period 2011–2016 in 60 places, spread over 13 [[Provinces of Thailand|provinces]] in every part of Thailand. The Counter Corruption Division and the NOB stated they found evidence of another 26 temples involved in illegal dealings, resulting in the loss of 102 to 106 million baht. Most budgets were meant to be used for repair and restoration.<ref name="TR 2018-05-27">{{cite news|title=ปปป.ลุยสอบทุจริตเงินทอนวัดลอต 4 เจอแล้ว 26 แห่ง เสียหายราว 100 ล้าน|trans-title=Counter Corruption Division active in 4th investigation temple fraud: 26 places found, approximately 100 M loss |url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1292674 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727164335/https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1292674 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=28 May 2018|work=[[Thai Rath]]|date=27 May 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=“วัชรพล”ยันจะเร่งสรุปเงินทอนวัดโดยเร็วที่สุด |trans-title=Wacharapol insists he will finish the temple fraud case as soon as possible |url=http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=307321 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727164339/http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=307321 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018|work=Lok Wannee|date=18 May 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=เงินทอนวัดล็อต4 รอผอ.พศ.แจ้งความ "วัดปากน้ำ-วัดพิชัยญาติ" <!--left untranslated per [[WP:CRIME]]-->|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MtgDTdibcm8 |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Nation TV (Thailand)|Nation TV]]|date=8 June 2018|format=Video|language=th}}</ref> Investigators said that the same network of civil servants, monks, and assistant laypersons was involved in the alleged scams.<ref>{{cite news|title=ฟอกเงินทอนวัด 'เอาผิดพระชั้นผู้ใหญ่'|trans-title=Senior monks implicated in temple fraud case money laundering |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vUuODQbKRSQ|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=27 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> {{nowrap|{{As of|2018|05|27|post=,}}}} four of the suspects had been fired,<ref>{{cite news|title=พบแล้ว 26 วัดทุจริตเงินทอนวัดล็อต 4| trans-title=26 places discovered in 4th temple fraud investigation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fb3jZnhAeuA|accessdate=28 May 2018|work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=27 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> and on 4 June, the high-ranking soldier implicated earlier had been imprisoned, though not fired.<ref>{{cite news |title=ผบ.ทสส.สั่งรองราชการ 'ร.ท.ฐิติทัตน์' โยงคดีเงินทอนวัด <!--left untranslated per [[WP:CRIME]]-->|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QvTZNrBM-m0 |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=4 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref> Bank records showed that the soldier and his mother had received millions of baht from Thai temples.<ref name="Thai PBS" /> The soldier had been ordained as a temporary novice in Wat Saket before this.<ref name="Nation 2017-07-03" /> Furthermore, the Thai police made a statement that Phra Phrom Sitthi had admitted during his imprisonment that the money transferred to the media production company was to avoid taxes, but was used by the temple and not laundered. The Thai police argued that the money was more likely used for personal purposes.<ref>{{cite news |title=แกะรอยเงินทอนวัดสระเกศ |trans-title=Tracing Wat Saket's changed money |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AQXoU7ArR7Y |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=[[New18]]|format=Video|date=14 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=ขยายผลเงินทอน 3 วัดดัง พบไม่ได้โอนกลับ พศ. แต่โอนไปบัญชีอื่น |trans-title=More results found in temple fraud case 3 well-known temples: they didn't transfer any money back, but transferred to other accounts |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p74rthG69_s |accessdate=21 June 2018|format=Video|date=14 June 2018 |language=th|time=2:30 }}</ref>
[[File:General Prayut Chan-o-cha (cropped).jpg|thumb|Military junta leader [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] criticized the online response to the 2018 arrests.| alt=Smiling Thai man in suit|upright=0.7|left]]
Pongporn expected to complete his investigations by September 2018.<ref name="TR 2018-05-27" /> Varaiyuth Suwatankhun, director of the Counter Corruption Division, stated that the main focus of the investigations was on civil servants, not monks.<ref>{{cite news |title=ผบก.ปปป.ลุยเงินทอนวัดลอต 4 |trans-title=Director Counter Corruption starts 4th temple fraud investigation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jmF4CUzBvQ |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[New18]]|format=Video|date=30 May 2018 |language=th}}</ref> Meanwhile, a number of news reporters doing field research in Thai temples found that some Thai temples were unaware of any financial dealings, because they were not informed about the amount of money involved in transfers, or presumed that the NOB, as an advisory organization, knew what was best.<ref name="Perdpom" />
In May 2018, the NOB announced they would seek out examples of temples that had good financial procedures. Provincial departments of the NOB were assigned to gather information.<ref>{{cite news |title=“ ทนายฯ วรกร “ ขู่ฟ้อง 157 ผอ.สำนักพุทธฯ อ้างไม่ยอมดำเนินคดี จนท.เอี่ยวเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=Lawyer Warakorn threatens to charge director NOB with section 157, stating director doesn't process lawsuits government officers implicated in temple fraud |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0A5hqh4KCOw |work=[[PPTV (Thailand)|PPTV]] |accessdate=13 June 2018|format=Video|date=12 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref name="NBT 2018-06-12" /> One objective of the provincial investigations was to check whether it would be possible to operate temples without monks handling the money.<ref name="Spring News" /> However, a network called the Federation of Lawyers Protecting Buddhism petitioned the NOB to stop the investigation, because the federation considered such an investigation illegitimate. Specifically, the federation argued that the NOB acted beyond its jurisdiction.<ref name="Spring News">{{cite news |title=ร้องกองปราบเอาผิด ขรก.เอี่ยวเงินทอนวัด | trans-title=Having Crime Suppression charge government officers implicated in temple fraud |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0LGrwAEqXGI |accessdate=13 June 2018 |work=[[Spring News]]|format=Video|date=13 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref name="NBT 2018-06-12">{{cite news |title=รัฐบาลยืนยันดำเนินการคดีเงินทอนวัดไม่มีอคติ |trans-title=Junta insists they handle lawsuits temple fraud unbiased |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUtZ3vOhHJc |accessdate=13 June 2018 |work=[[National Broadcasting Services of Thailand]]|format=Video|date=12 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref> A representative of the NOB responded that they were just trying to gather information, to which the federation responded by suing the NOB for negligence in official duties.<ref name="Thai PBS 2018-06-12" /> Meanwhile, junta leader [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] responded to an increase in monks criticizing the investigations on social networks, questioning whether this was appropriate for monks.<ref name="Thai PBS 2018-06-12">{{cite news |title=นายกฯ ย้ำคดีเงินทอนวัดตามหลักฐาน |trans-title=PM emphasizes that temple fraud case is evidence-based |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=viit_mJ-qMA |accessdate=13 June 2018 |work=[[Thai PBS]]|format=Video|date=12 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref name="NBT 2018-06-12" /> He added that "security measures" might be required.<ref>{{cite news |title=ข่าวข้นคนเนชั่น |trans-title=People News Intense, from The Nation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zE2NNOt3Sw8 |work=[[Nation TV (Thailand)|Nation TV]] |accessdate=13 June 2018|date=12 June 2018|format=Video|language=th}}</ref>
On 20 June, Pongporn held a press conference defending the provincial investigations, stating that he was acting in accordance with the law but did not have the "authority to manage the temples". He further added that in the first two investigations, the main fault was the NOB itself, but in the third the fault was with the monks arrested, due to evidence indicating "money laundering". He concluded by insisting that any temple aware of any government officials involved in temple scams should report this to the NOB, and they would investigate.<ref>{{cite news |title=ผอ.พศ.แจงทุกปมร้อนวงการสงฆ์ |trans-title=Director NOB makes statement about every hot issue of Saṅgha |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7VOPCUdTpI |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=[[Thai News Agency]] |publisher=[[MCOT]]|format=Video|date=20 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref><ref name="INN">{{cite news |title=พศ.ยันเอาผิดข้าราชการเอี่ยวเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=NOB director insists to charge government officers implicated in temple fraud |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9keHFzbSMT4 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=[[INN (Thailand)]]|format=Video|date=20 June 2018 |language=th |time=3:00 }}</ref> The federation and several other networks, however, recommended that any temples that had {{em|received any budget}} from the NOB should report this to the local police immediately, and report to the police that they would completely cooperate with any legal action against the NOB and be a witness in such cases.<ref name="INN" />
== Responses and analysis == The arrests have been widely regarded by journalists and news analysts as unprecedented and a critical blow to the faith of Thai Buddhist devotees.<ref name="TR 2018-05-28">{{cite news|title=ปฏิรูปวงการสงฆ์ครั้งใหญ่ |trans-title=Large reform of Saṅgha |url=https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1292526 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727164649/https://www.thairath.co.th/content/1292526 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=28 May 2018|work=Thai Rath|date=28 May 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref name="Khemthong" /><ref name="Taylor" />
=== Foreign === French political journalist Arnaud Dubus and law scholar Khemthong Tonsakulrungruang wrote that the fraud investigations were symptomatic of problem of mismanagement and corruption within the Saṅgha. Though the problems should be dealt with, the NCPO was unlikely to be able to do this because they themselves had problems of [[Corruption in Thailand|corruption]] and lacked political legitimacy.<ref name="Khemthong">{{cite news |last1=Tonsakulrungruang |first1=Khemthong |title=Purging the Thai Sangha |url=http://www.newmandala.org/ncpos-purge-thai-sangha/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727164656/http://www.newmandala.org/ncpos-purge-thai-sangha/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=New Mandala |date=28 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Dubus |first1=Arnaud |title=La junte lance une opération transparence pour la communauté monastique bouddhiste |trans-title=The junta launches a transparency operation for the Buddhist monastic community |url=http://eglasie.mepasie.org/asie-du-sud-est/thailande/2018-05-31-la-junte-lance-une-campagne-dassainissement-de-la-communaute-monastique-bouddhiste |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727164701/http://eglasie.mepasie.org/asie-du-sud-est/thailande/2018-05-31-la-junte-lance-une-campagne-dassainissement-de-la-communaute-monastique-bouddhiste |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=[[Eglises d'Asie]] |date=31 May 2018 |language=fr}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' stated that the timing of the investigations and subsequent raids were a clear indication that they were politically motivated, as the junta tried to assert greater control over the Thai Sangha before the next election. Paul Chambers, a lecturer at [[Naresuan University]], claimed the arrests were done to take control of any monks who were not loyal to the [[National Council for Peace and Order]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/26/thailands-junta-renews-corruption-crackdown-on-buddhist-monks |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727165730/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/26/thailands-junta-renews-corruption-crackdown-on-buddhist-monks |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |title=Thailand's junta renews corruption crackdown on Buddhist monks|last=Ellis-Petersen|first=Hannah|date=26 June 2018|work=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=30 June 2018}}</ref>
Anthropologist Jim Taylor wrote that the arrests were likely politically motivated, arguing that the investigations and subsequent arrests represented the "[[network monarchy|ruling palace regime]]" trying to consolidate traditional, central royalist power by eliminating several non-royalist high-ranking monks and members of the [[Sangha Supreme Council]].<ref name="Taylor">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Jim |title=What's behind the 'purging' of the Thai sangha? |url=http://www.newmandala.org/whats-behind-purging-thai-sangha/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727164706/http://www.newmandala.org/whats-behind-purging-thai-sangha/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=New Mandala |date=8 June 2018}}</ref> Taylor argued that this was done in order to take control of several wealthy temples and ensure that the next [[Supreme Patriarch of Thailand|leader of the Thai Saṅgha]] is a royalist, pro-junta monk, pointing to the junta's [[Wat Paknam Bhasicharoen#Appointment withdrawn (2015–17)|previous interference with the position]] in 2017. Taylor also pointed out that the suspects of the investigations were [[innocent until proven guilty]], yet were defrocked before trial and stripped of decades of monastic seniority solely on the basis of unproven accusations.<ref name="Taylor" />
=== Domestic === [[File:นายไพบูลย์ นิติตะวัน.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|{{ill|Paiboon Nititawan|th|ไพบูลย์_นิติตะวัน}} agreed with the 2018 arrests.|alt=Government officer in military-style suit]]
Representatives of the Thai monastic community responded to the arrests dumbfounded and saddened. Chao Khun Kasem, head of southern ecclesiastical regions and head of a pro-Buddhist network, accused the Thai junta of lack of transparency.<ref name="Jomquan" /> Chao Khun Kasem, as well as Jaroon Wannakasinanont, leader of several pro-Buddhist networks, stated that the government should deal with its own officials first, and only after that deal with the monks involved,<ref name="TNA" /><ref name="TNN24" /><ref name="TNN24 18-06-01">{{cite news |title=ตร.พบเบาะแสอดีตพระพรหมเมธีหนีข้ามโขงไปสปป.ลาว |trans-title=Police finds evidence formerly Phra Phrom Methee fled, crossing Mekong into Laos |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uki-IMgRzHI |accessdate=10 June 2018|format=Video|date=1 June 2018 |work=[[TNN24]] |language=th}}</ref> if the monks were guilty at all.<ref name="TNA" /> He argued that if the allocated budget was not used exactly as requested, but was still used for public rather than personal purposes, it was not a serious fault.<ref name="Perdpom" /><ref name="Jomquan 18-04-25" /> Pisit Lilawachiropas, former member of the State Audit Office of Thailand, and Korn Meedee, chairman of the Thailand Buddhists Federation, said accusations against temples were not clear. They mentioned that the categories in the budget request procedure were very broad, and therefore different interpretations in applying the budget were likely.<ref name="Jomquan 18-04-25">{{cite news|last1=Laopetchr|first1=Jomquan|title=สอบกรรมการมหาเถรฯ ทุจริต ตอน 1|trans-title=Questioning Sangha Council about fraud, part 1 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rDnJSY7j9kY|work=[[Thai Rath]]|format=Video|date=25 April 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Laopetchr|first1=Jomquan|title=สอบกรรมการมหาเถรฯ ทุจริต ตอน 2 |trans-title=Questioning Sangha Council about fraud, part 2 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l1OMTlAkdk8|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[Thai Rath]]|format=Video|date=26 April 2018|language=th}}</ref> Chao Khun Kasem stated that officials often grant large sums to decrease paperwork, and sometimes use the same budget for several temples.<ref name="TNA" /> Pricha Puemprasith, a scholar at the [[Thammasart University]], stated that Pongporn's very position as director of the NOB was questionable, because he was appointed by the junta rather than by Buddhist representatives.<ref name="TNA">{{cite news|title=ข่าวค่ำ (ในประเทศ) ช่วงที่ 1 |trans-title=Evening news (inside Thailand), part 1 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y5AeQfph8Do|accessdate=28 May 2018|work=[[Thai News Agency]]|publisher=[[MCOT]]|format=Video|date=27 May 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0hwZunO0Xqo|title=มหาเถรสมาคม “ระส่ำ”...? “3 พระเถระ” เอี่ยว “โกงเงินโรงเรียนสงฆ์”|last1=Chimmanee|first1=Worawith|date=18 April 2018|work=Thai PBS|format=Video|accessdate=27 May 2018|language=th|trans-title=SSC disorganized? 3 senior monks steal money for monastic school}}</ref>
The investigations and subsequent arrests have been described as politically motivated.<ref name="Jomquan">{{cite news|last1=Laopetchr|first1=Jomquan|title=ล้างบาง วงการสงฆ์ |trans-title=Elimination of the Saṅgha |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TSWI4wZ8aks|accessdate=26 May 2018|work=Thai Rath|format=Video|date=25 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="TNN24">{{cite news|title=ทางออกการแก้ปัญหาคดีเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=Solution for temple fraud case |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wRvLMSG5K1g|accessdate=26 May 2018|work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=23 May 2018|language=th}}</ref> Specifically, Korn has speculated that the arrest of the three Sangha Council members was a form of political revenge. According to Korn, the three council members had been instrumental in removing Pongporn from his position in August 2017. Moreover, they were understood to have connections with the [[United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship]] that opposed the junta, and were therefore seen as a threat.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Petpradap|first1=Jom|title="แค้น-การเมือง"เบื้องหลังกำจัด"พระเถระ-มส."กรณีทุจริตทอนเงินวัด |trans-title=Revenge and politics: behind the removal of Sangha Council senior monks, temple fraud case |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=igZAmZ4yZYQ|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=Thaivoice|format=Video|date=20 April 2018|language=th}}</ref> Critics of the junta have argued that the high-profile arrests were an attempt to cover up the military government's own failings.<ref name="Dubus" />
On 25 July 2017, several influential monks, among them Chao Khun Pipit, asked for a {{ill|traditional, monastic boycott|th|การคว่ำบาตร (ศาสนาพุทธ)}} of the NOB, calling upon tens of thousands of Thai administrative monks to suspend communications with them.<ref name="Now26">{{cite news |title=ปมร้อนเขย่าเงินวัดแสนล้าน "สังฆาธิการ" เปิดศึก "พศ." |trans-title=Hot issue messing up 100.000 M temple's money, abbots start a battle with NOB |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RRss0RQEpfI |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[Now26]]|format=Video |date=25 July 2017 |language=th}}</ref> This eventually led to the temporary suspension of Pongporn's position as director in August 2017. On 1 June 2018, Jaroon, in the name of several pro-Buddhist networks, charged Pongporn with fraud and negligence in official duties,<ref name="TNN24 18-06-01" /> after unsuccessfully petitioning several government departments.<ref name="Bangkok Post">{{cite news |last1=Nathanri |first1=Jakkrapan |last2=Nanuam |first2=Wassana |title=Lines draw in Buddhist battle over temple funds |url=https://www.pressreader.com/thailand/bangkok-post/20180426/281560881401741 |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=Bangkok Post |via=PressReader.com |date=26 April 2018}}</ref> Pongporn defended his actions in 2017 and again in June 2018, stating that most of the suspects were government officials, but if monks were involved, he had to follow procedures.<ref name="INN" /><ref name="Now26" /> Similarly, Varaiyuth and his colleague Kamol Rianracha stated in their defense that the main targets of the investigations were government officials rather than Thai temples, which, in the words of Varaiyuth, tended to be "the prey of government officers".<ref name="Now26" /><ref>{{cite news |title=รายงาน ย้อนเส้นทางสืบสวนคดีเงินทอนวัด |trans-title=Report: tracing investigations temple fraud |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gi3p7rVsnH8 |accessdate=12 June 2018|format=Video|work=[[New18]] |date=12 June 2018 |language=th}}</ref>
There were also people who supported the investigations and arrests, arguing that it helped improve the monastic community.<ref name="TR 2018-05-28" /> Paiboon stated that the arrests were good riddance. He said that budgets were often abused by temples and since leading monks were considered civil servants under the law, they should take responsibility.<ref name="Benar" /><ref name="Jomquan 18-04-25" /> [[Wissanu Krea-ngam]], [[Prime Minister of Thailand#Deputy Prime Ministers|Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand]], made a statement that he did not expect [[Buddhism in Thailand|Thai Buddhism]] to be affected much by the events.<ref name="NBT">{{cite news|title=รองนายกฯระบุ คดีเงินทอนวัด ไม่กระทบศรัทธาต่อพระพุทธศาสนา |trans-title=Deputy PM states temple fraud case doesn't affect faith in Buddhism |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TyoKUmbLfLM|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[National Broadcasting Services of Thailand]]|format=Video|date=25 May 2018|language=th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=“ฉัตรชัย” ย้ำจนท.บุกสอบเงินทอนวัดดังยึดกม |trans-title=Chatrchai repeats that officers investigating temple fraud well-known temples is lawful |url=http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=308062 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20180727165552/http://www.lokwannee.com/web2013/?p=308062 |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=27 May 2018 |work=Lok Wannee |date=24 May 2018 |language=th |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Ariyavongsagatanana (Amborn Ambaro)|Somdet Phra Ariyavongsagatanana]], the [[Supreme Patriarch of Thailand|Supreme Patriarch]] of the Thai monastic community, said he was "concerned with the current state of Buddhism", but that he understood that the authorities needed to take action. He further requested that "all organizations properly explain to the public" what was going on.<ref name="BEC 2018-05-26" />
== Subsequent political reform == The fraud investigations have led to some ideas for political reform. Back in 2017, Pongporn stated that the structure of the NOB had been greatly improved on and subsequent fraud was less likely. In particular, more oversight had been built into the budget request procedures. Pongporn also proposed more government control over the finances of Thai temples.<ref name="TNN 2017-06-09">{{cite news|title=เปิดเส้นทางทุจริต"เงินทอน"งบอุดหนุนวัด |trans-title=Revealing the path of fraud in temple subsidies |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ituCBB4Ocfs|accessdate=27 May 2018|work=[[TNN24]]|format=Video|date=9 June 2017|language=th}}</ref> On a similar note, Paiboon argued that every Thai temple should have an independent lay accountant.<ref name="Benar" />
Pricha argued that the fraud investigations point to a larger problem, that is, the Sangha Council was responsible for too many matters, without proper organization and independent oversight—the council was responsible for [[legislature|legislative]], [[executive (government)|executive]], and [[judiciary|judicial]] powers, with no [[Separation of powers|division of these functions]].<ref name="TNA" /> Journalist [[Pravit Rojanaphruk]]<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rojanaphruk |first1=Pravit |authorlink1=Pravit Rojanaphruk |title=The Corruption and Excesses of Thai Buddhism |url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/opinion/2018/06/02/the-corruption-and-excesses-of-thai-buddhism/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727170053/http://www.khaosodenglish.com/opinion/2018/06/02/the-corruption-and-excesses-of-thai-buddhism/ |archive-date=27 July 2018 |dead-url=no |accessdate=10 June 2018 |work=Khaosod English|date=2 June 2018}}</ref> and Buddhist scholar Vichak Panich<ref name="Straight" /> argued that the fraud investigations pointed to a larger problem of the Thai [[separation of church and state|state and religion being intermingled]].
On 5 July 2018, the Thai junta amended the Saṅgha Act. An important implication of the amendment was that members of the Sangha Council were chosen by the [[King of Thailand|Thai King]], instead of being chosen by members of the Saṅgha themselves. Proposed by the Thai Cabinet, the amendment was unanimously approved by the [[National Legislative Assembly of Thailand (2014)|National Legislative Assembly of Thailand]], a government department the junta had set up since the 2014 coup. Wissanu Krea-ngam explained that the Saṅgha Council was "too old" and "often ill", which made it difficult to appoint their own members and to deal with the "current crisis". The new members would normally be appointed in September.<ref>{{cite news |title=สนช.เห็นชอบร่างแก้ไขเพิ่มเติม พ.ร.บ.คณะสงฆ์ |trans-title=National Legislative Assembly approves amendment of Saṅgha Act |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GJMPaW05MBQ |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=[[National Broadcasting Services of Thailand]]|format=Video|date=5 July 2018 |language=th}}</ref> Korn Meedee complained that too little time was given for the Saṅgha to oppose or give their opinion on the amendment and even if they submitted their response in time, the National Legislative Assembly did not respond. After the amendment had been finalized, Korn stated that Buddhist organizations could no longer protest against the new act due to risk of violating the strict law on [[lèse majesté in Thailand]]. He did add, however, that pro-Buddhist networks did not object to the role of the Thai king, but felt it was possible the junta would choose the members instead, citing the king's authority.<ref>{{cite news |last=Petpradap |first1=Jom |title=พรรคแผ่นดินธรรม ชูธง ปกป้องพุทธศาสนา ย้ำแก้”กม.สงฆ์”ต้องถามพระและชาวพุทธ |trans-title=Phaendin Tham Party shows a clear stance in protecting Buddhism, affirms that monks and Buddhists should be asked about Saṅgha Act |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k8J36PJddp0 |accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=4 July 2018|format=Video|work=Thaivoice |language=th}}</ref>

{{MEX}} |- | '''Region''' || [[Mesoamerica]] ([[México]]) |- |'''Coordinates''' || {{coord|19|19|42.74|N|98|53|33.35|W|type:city|display=inline,title}} |- | '''Culture''' || [[Chichimeca]] – [[Acolhua]] – [[Tepanec]] |- | '''Language''' || |- | '''Chronology''' || 900 - 1521 CE. |- | '''Period''' || Classical - Postclassical |- | ''' [[INAH]] Web Page ''' || [https://web.archive.org/web/20100910144816/http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00903.html Acozac Archaeological site (Spanish)] |} '''Acozac''' (Ixtapaluca) is an [[archaeological site]] located in the Municipality of [[Ixtapaluca]], [[State of Mexico]], [[Mexico]]. The site is at kilometer 30 of federal road México - Puebla, towards Ixtapaluca. == The site== Has been linked with Tlazallan - Tlallanoztoc, ([[Codex Xolotl]]) as the grandson of Xólotl Techotlallatzin cities site. Ceramic evidence indicates the site had occupation at the following periods: foundation probably started in Azteca I phase (900 to 1,200 CE), and continued with Aztec phase II (1200 to 1430) (Techotlallatzin reign). Azteca phase III (1430 to 1521) structures are currently visible.{{cite web|title=INAH ACOZAC Web Page |trans-title=Acozac Archaeological Site |url=http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00903.html |work=INAH |publisher=Archaeologist Raúl Ernesto García Chávez |language=Spanish |accessdate=2010-09-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910144816/http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00903.html |archivedate=10 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Techotlallatzin, Texcoco ''[[tlatoani]]'' died in 1406, his son [[Itzcoatl]] took his place, an inexperienced Prince and was surprised at his city, by [[Tezozomoc (Azcapotzalco)|Tezozomoc]], [[Azcapotzalco]] ''tlatoani'', escaped with his son [[Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani)|Nezahualcoyotl]] in arms. He was chased up a forest, where he managed to hide the baby before being killed.{{cite web|title=Señores Mexica|url=http://www.arts-history.mx/sitios/index.php?id_sitio=185352&id_seccion=733172&id_subseccion=765375&id_documento=999|work=Arts & History|publisher=|language=Spanish|accessdate=2010-09-21}} == Structures == Circular temple is dedicated to worship [[Ehecatl]], "the wind god". The Great Platform (between the circular temple and the Palace), the structure has rooms, patios and altars; some red stucco finishing remains to date; also, two small altars were found near the foundation of the main temple and in front in the lower part. Over a hundred structures have been detected, presumably for residential use. From the site the volcanoes [[Popocatepetl]] and [[Iztaccihuatl]] can be seen, the site is in the middle of a forest, and the construction remains can be seen, in addition to the natural landscape. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100821184438/http://www.visitingmexico.com.mx/turismo-en-mexico/arqueologico/tur-arqueologico-estado-mexico.php Visiting Mexico: Turismo Arqueológico en Estado de México] {{es icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Acozac (Archaeological Site)}} [[Category:Mesoamerican sites]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Mexico]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in the State of Mexico]] [[Category:Former populated places in Mexico]] [[Category:Ixtapaluca]] [[Category:Populated places in the State of Mexico]] [[Category:Altepetl]] [[Category:Aztec sites]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in the State of Mexico]]

{{distinguish|Awl (disambiguation){{!}}Awl}} {{refimprove|date=December 2015}} [[Image:PG - Dagestan. Shamil's village (colour).jpg|thumb|250px|[[Gunib]], an aul in Dagestan, as photographed by [[Prokudin-Gorsky]] at some point between 1905 and 1915.]] An '''aul''' ({{lang-ce|oil}}, {{lang-ru|аул}}, [[Turkic languages|Turkic]]: ''awıl'') is a type of fortified village found throughout the [[Caucasus]] mountains.
==Etymology== The word itself is of Turkic origin and simply means ''village'' in many Turkic languages.
Auyl ({{lang-kk|Ауыл}}) is a Kazakh word meaning "village" in [[Kazakhstan]].<ref>Қазақ тілі термиңдерінің салалық ғылыми түсіндірме сөздігі: География және геодезия. — Алматы: "Мектеп" баспасы, 2007. — 264 бет. {{ISBN|9965-36-367-6}}</ref>
==Description== The auls of [[Svaneti]] (in the [[Georgia (country)|Republic of Georgia]]), with their distinctive medieval towers, have been recognized as a [[World Heritage Site]].<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/709 "Upper Svaneti - UNESCO World Heritage Centre"], ''UNESCO World Heritage Centre'', United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization.</ref> Comparable towers may be found elsewhere in the Caucasus, specifically in [[Ingushetia]].
The auls are generally built out of stone, on faces of ridges or against cliffs in order to provide protection against surprise attacks. Houses are usually two stories high, and they are staggered to make it virtually impossible for enemies to get anywhere on the roads. The houses usually have a southern aspect to take advantage of the sun in the winter and to be sheltered from the northern winds. Often, they are not located near good farmland or water sources, so it is necessary to bring water into the settlement.
In the 19th century, as [[Russian Empire|Russia]] fought to [[Caucasian War|conquer the Caucasus]], auls were very formidable defences and could be taken for the most part only by storming. There are many famous auls in [[Chechnya]] which the Russians could not reach.{{cn|date=December 2015}}

{{Distinguish|Bangla language|Mbangala language|Ngala language (disambiguation){{!}}Ngla language}} {{Infobox language |name=Bangala
|altname=Ngala |states=[[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Republic of the Congo]] |region=[[Haut-Uele District]] |speakers="few" |date=no date |speakers2=3.5 million [[L2 speakers]] (1991) |ref=e15 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantoid languages|Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone C|Zone C]]) |fam6=[[Bangi–Ntomba languages|Bangi–Ntomba]] (C.30) |fam7=Bangi–Moi |fam8=[[Bangi language|Bangi]] |fam9=[[Lingala]]? |iso3=bxg |glotto=bang1353 |glottorefname=Bangala |guthrie=C30A }}
'''Bangala''' is a [[Bantu language]] spoken in the northeast corner of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[South Sudan]] and the extreme western part of [[Uganda]]. A divergent form of [[Lingala language|Lingala]], it is used as a [[lingua franca]] by people with different languages and rarely as a first language. The estimated number of speakers varies between 2 and 3.5 million.<ref>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=bxg Ethnologue.com: Bangala - A language of the Democratic Republic of Congo]</ref> It is spoken to the east and northeast of the area where Lingala is spoken. In Lingala, Bangala translates to "People of [[Mongala]]" this means people living along the [[Mongala River]]
==History== As Lingala spread east and north, its vocabulary was replaced more and more by tribal and regional languages, and it became more of an [[interlanguage]] (a language that is a mix of two or more languages) and was classified as a separate language – Bangala. The vocabulary varies, depending on the first language of the speakers.
Around the 1980s, with the popularity and increased availability of Lingala in modern music, young people in large villages and towns began adopting Lingala so much that their Bangala is becoming more of a dialect than a separate language.<ref>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=bxg Ethnologue.com: Bangala - A language of the Democratic Republic of Congo]</ref>
==Characteristics== In Bangala, the words for six and seven (''motoba, sambo'') are replaced with the [[Swahili language|Swahili]] words ''sita'' and ''saba''. Many Lingala words are replaced by words in Swahili, [[Zande language|Zande]], other local languages, plus English (''bilizi'' is derived from the English word bridge) and, of course, French.
The verb "to be" is conjugated differently in Bangala. Below is a comparison with Lingala. {| class="wikitable" |- ! English !! Lingala !! Bangala |- | I am|| nazali || nazi |- | you are (singular) || ozali || ozi |- | he/she is || azali || azi |- | it is || ezali || ezi |- | we are || tozali || tozi |- | you are (plural) || bozali || bozi |- | they are || bazali || bazi |} The verb prefix ''ko-'', meaning "to" in Lingala is instead ''ku'', as it is in Swahili, so "to be" in Bangala is ''kusala'', not ''kosala''. Many other Bangala words have an /u/ sound where Lingala has an /o/ sound, such as ''bisu'' (not ''biso'' - "we") and ''mutu'' (not ''moto'' - "person").
