==Effects on motherhood and family structure== [[File:Crain Unit Sign.jpg|thumb|[[Christina Crain Unit]], a state prison for women in [[Gatesville, Texas|Gatesville]], [[Texas]]]] [[File:Women's Huron Valley Correctional Facility.JPG|thumb|[[Women's Huron Valley Correctional Facility]] in [[Pittsfield Township, Michigan]]]] [[File:Lowell Correctional Institution welcome.gif|thumb|[[Lowell Correctional Institution]] in [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] [[Marion County, Florida]]]] Prison can have an effect on [[Relationships for incarcerated individuals|relationships between prisoners and their children]]. As a general rule, except for with an experimental trial, a couple cannot enter the same prison. However, prisons have a problem with child care. 2.4 million American children have a parent behind bars today. Seven million, or 1 in 10 children, have a parent under criminal justice supervision—in jail or prison, on probation, or on parole.<ref>{{cite book|last=Solinger|first=Rickie|title=Interrupted Life:Experiences of Incarcerated Women in the United States|year=2010|publisher=University of California|location=Berkely, CA.|pages=37}}</ref> Many of the women incarcerated are single mothers who are subsequently characterized as inadequate, incompetent, and unable to provide for their children during and after imprisonment. However, "separation from and concern about the well-being of their children are among the most damaging aspects of prison for women, and the problem is exacerbated by a lack of contact".<ref>{{cite book|last=Travis|first=Jeremy|title=Prisoners Once Removed: The Impact of Incarceration and Reentry on Children, Families and Communities|year=2003|publisher=The Urban Institute Press|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=76}}</ref>
According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, "54% of mothers in state prisons as of 2000 had had no personal visits with their children since their admission".<ref>{{cite book|last=Travis|first=Jeremy|title=Prisoners Once Removed: The Impact of Incarceration and Reentry on Children, Families and Communities|year=2003|publisher=The Urban Institute Press|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=77}}</ref> Obstacles that inhibit contact between mothers and their children include geographical distance, lack of transportation, lack of privacy, inability to cover travel expenses, and the inappropriate environments of correctional facilities. Mothers in prison typically are unable to fulfill the role of mother due to the separation. Incarcerated mothers are restricted in their decision-making power and their ability to create a sense of home and family within the institution is limited.<ref>Luther, Kate, and Joanna Gregson. "Restricted Motherhood: Parenting in a Prison Nursery."International Journal of Sociology of the Family 37.1 (2011): 85-104. Print.</ref> Most children experience multiple risks across contextual levels for there is great importance in family environments. Children of incarcerated mothers are consistent with their high risk status and it can cause their intellectual outcomes to be compromised.<ref>Poehlmann, Julie. "Children's Family Environments And Intellectual Outcomes During Maternal Incarceration." Journal of Marriage & Family 67.5 (2005): 1275-1285.Women's Studies International. Web. 16 Mar. 2012.</ref> Statistics indicate "that a majority of parents in state and federal prisons are held over 100 miles from their prior residence; in federal prison 43% of parents are held 500 miles away from their last home, and over half of female prisoners have never had a visit from their children and very few mothers speak with their children by phone while incarcerated".<ref name="Sentencing Project" />
Recent legislation has further impeded an incarcerated mother's ability to sustain custody of her children. The [[Adoption and Safe Families Act]], enacted in 1997, "authorizes the termination of parental rights once a child has been in foster care for 15 or more months of a 22-month period. Incarcerated women serve an average of 18 months in prison. Therefore, the average female prisoner whose children are placed in foster care could lose the right to reunite with her children upon release".<ref>{{cite book|last=Travis|first=Jeremy|title=Prisoners Once Removed: The Impact of Incarceration and Reentry on Children, Families and Communities|year=2003|publisher=The Urban Institute Press|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=25}}</ref> These stipulations expedite the termination of parental rights due to the narrow time frame. A 2003 study found that "termination proceedings involving incarcerated parents increased from approximately 260 in 1997, the year of ASFA's enactment, to 909 in 2002".<ref name="Law 2009 45">{{cite book|last=Law|first=Victoria|title=Resistance Behind Bars: The Struggles of Incarcerated Women|year=2009|publisher=PM Press|location=Oakland|pages=45}}</ref>
By examining post-incarcerated mothers, it is statistically and clinically proven that there is a positive effect of a healthy mother-child relationship and depression symptoms. There is also a positive effect of healthy peer and partner relationships on raising self-esteem for mothers who were previously incarcerated. This suggests that healthy relationships are essential to recovery from trauma and emotional well-being.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Walker | first1 = Erin K. | title = Risk and protective factors in mothers with a history of incarceration: do relationships buffer the effects of trauma symptoms and substance abuse history? | journal = [[Women & Therapy]] | volume = 34 | issue = 4 | pages = 359–376 | publisher = Taylor and Francis | doi = 10.1080/02703149.2011.591662 | date = 2011 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/02703149.2011.591662 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
According to a 2000 report by the Bureau of Justice Statistics, "1/3 of incarcerated mothers lived alone with their children and over 2/3 of women prisoners have children under the age of 18; among them only 28% said that their children were living with the father while 90% of male prisoners with minor children said their children were living with their mothers."<ref name="Law 2009 45"/>
The incarceration of parents affect family structures.<ref name=gjyc>{{cite journal|last=Graham|first=James A.|author2=Yvette R. Harris|title=Children of Color and Parental Incarceration: Implications for Research, Theory, and Practice|journal=Journal of Multicultural Counseling and Development|date=2013|volume=41.2|issue=2|pages=66–81|doi=10.1002/j.2161-1912.2013.00028.x}}<!--|accessdate=3 May 2014--></ref> Mothers in prison were more likely to report that they were the primary caregivers of their children.<ref name="gjyc"/> Maternal imprisonment affects children more harshly than the incarceration of their fathers. When the paternal figure of a home is convicted, children are affected, but they don't experience the same kind of attachment disparity as they do with their mothers. "When fathers go to prison, their children are more likely to remain in the care of their mothers; however, when mothers go to prison, not only are children separated from their mother but they more often transition to the care of a grandparent, or other family member, than to the care of their other parent ".<ref name=":10">{{cite journal|last1=Dallaire|first1=D. H.|year=2007|title=Incarcerated Mothers and Fathers: A Comparison of Risks for Children and Families|url=|journal=Family Relations|volume=56|issue=|pages=440–453|doi=10.1111/j.1741-3729.2007.00472.x}}</ref> In the case that there is no family member able to take the children in, they are taken into non-familiar care. Children who grow up without their parents tend to have a higher chance of engaging in "substance abuse and addiction, mental illness, and abusive familial relationships".<ref name=":10" />
There are limited employment opportunities after incarceration.<ref name="gjyc"/> Reduced opportunities for parents means reduced opportunities for their children who cannot access those resources denied to their parents, such as food stamps or employment.<ref name="gjyc"/> In addition, for communities where the majority of the population are targets for incarceration and where there are high incarceration rates, those economies are affected.<ref name="gjyc"/> In addition to poor economies, limited employment opportunities, and high incarceration rates in those communities, there is the creation of a "criminogenic environment" which affects the children growing up in those areas.<ref name="gjyc"/>
Women in the US criminal justice system are marginalized by race and class. Single mothers with low income go into the "underground economies" because of their inability to find a job that is stable and provides a good earning.<ref name=kgmw>{{cite journal|last=Kirk|first=Gwyn|author2=Margo Okazawa-Rey |title=Women's lives: Multicultural perspectives|journal=Mayfield Pub.|date=1998}}</ref> Many mothers end up trapped in drugs, prostitution and theft.<ref name="kgmw"/> In many cases, incarcerated women who committed acts of violence are for self-defense against their abusive partners.<ref name="kgmw"/>
Bureau of Justice reported that about 200,000 children under 18 had incarcerated mothers and that 1.5 million children had a parent behind bars.<ref name="kgmw"/> Children face disruption and deleterious where they feel separated from the world such as their friends, school and community.(1) It can bring integration into their new world without their mother.<ref name=sjd>{{cite book|last=Siegel|first=Jane A.|title=Disrupted childhoods: Children of women in prison|date=2011|publisher=Rutgers University Press}}</ref> 6.7 percent of African American children have incarcerated parents, a rate that is seven-and-a-half times greater than that of white children. Hispanic children experience parental incarceration at nearly three times the rate that white children do (Glaze and MAruchak 2008)<ref name="kgmw"/> Children feel the mother absences and experience disruption more than the absences of their incarcerated father. "64.2 percent of mothers in prison report they were living with their children before they went to prison, only 46.5 percent of incarcerated fathers did so."<ref name=sjd/> "Men are more likely to rely on their children's mothers to care for the children during their incarceration than women can on the children father. 88 percent of fathers in prison report that their children are being cared for by their child's mother while only 37 percent of inmate mothers say their child is being cared for by the child's father" (PG.4 Disrupted childhoods: Children of women in prison.)<ref name=sjd/> Children in most cases stay with relatives such as grandparents and 10 percent in foster care, group homes or social service agencies.<ref name="kgmw"/> The Children often feel stigma for having a parent in prison where they may feel the need to keep it a secret where they are not able to adjust.<ref name=sjd/> Most of the time these children are at risk of following their parents footsteps where they might become criminals by learning the behavior such as antisocial and criminal behavior. Caregivers and teachers see the child of inmates fighting more and becoming aggressive leading them to have a higher risk of conviction.<ref name=sjd/>
Most prisons do not have public transport, restrictive policies governing visits and phone calls. Prisons have policies such as the removal of infants born to women in prison, speedy termination of child custody for incarcerated women, restrictive welfare policies that make it difficult for families to be reunited, and women repeated periods in custody.<ref name="kgmw"/> Activists are trying to make a change and pass reforms that are going to help children and mothers deal with these consequences that are affecting them. One guideline that would help is a family connections policy framework to support and strengthen the relationship between incarcerated women and their children.<ref name="kgmw"/> If women are able to see their children, it gives them motivation to try to get their lives back on track.<ref name="kgmw"/>
There is 6.7 percent of African American children whose parents are incarcerated, a rate that is seven and half times greater than that for white children, and Hispanic children experience parental incarceration at nearly three times the rate that white children do.<ref name="kgmw"/> Children feel the mother absences and experience disruption than their father. "Men are more likely to rely on their children mothers to care for the children during their incarceration than women can on the children father. 88 percent of father in prison report that their children are being cared for by their child mother while only 37 percent of inmate mothers say their child is being cared for by the child's father".<ref name=sjd/> Children in most cases stay with relatives such as grandparents and 10 percent in foster care, group home or social service agency.<ref name="kgmw"/> Children often feel stigma for having a parent in prison where they may feel the need to keep it a secret where they are not able to adjust.<ref name=sjd/> Most of the time these children are at risk to follow in the footsteps of their parents where they might become criminals by learning the behavior. Caregivers and teachers see the children of criminals fighting more and becoming aggressive leading them to have a higher risk of conviction.<ref name=sjd/>
Prisons prevent contact between the mothers and their children in many ways. The locations of the prisons might not have a public transport, restrictive policies governing visits and phone calls, the removal of infants born to women in prison, speedy termination of child custody for incarcerated women, restrictive welfare policies that make it difficult for families to be reunited, and women repeated periods in custody.<ref name="kgmw"/> Some activist are trying to make a change and pass reforms that are going to help children and mothers to not deal with this consequences that are effecting them. One guideline that would help is a family connections policy framework to support and strengthen the relationship between incarcerated women and their children.<ref name="kgmw"/> If women are able to see their children, it gives them motivation to try to get their lives back on track.<ref name="kgmw"/>
==Demographics of incarcerated parents and their children== The most common age range for incarcerated parents is from age 25 to 35, followed by age 35 to 44 and age 24 and younger.<ref name="gjyc"/> In mid-2007, 809,800 prisoners in the US prison system were parents to children 18 years of age or younger.<ref name="gjyc"/> Of those prisoners, 744,200 were fathers and 65,600 were mothers.<ref name="gjyc"/> In comparison to 1991, this data shows the number of women in prison has more than doubled and the number of fathers incarcerated has increased by seventy-seven percent.<ref name="gjyc"/> According to studies by the Bureau of Justice Statistics, 1,706,600 children had at least one incarcerated parent in 2007.<ref name="gjyc"/>
===Children of incarcerated parents=== :see also [[Relationships for incarcerated individuals#Children of incarcerated parents]] The most common age range for children with at least one incarcerated parent is from 0–9 years old, followed by children from 10 to 17 years old.<ref name="gjyc"/> In terms of racial demographics of children with incarcerated parents, Latino children are three times more likely to have a parent in prison in comparison to white children.<ref name="gjyc"/> Black children are about eight times more likely to have a parent in prison in comparison to white children.<ref name="gjyc"/> Nearly half of the children with an incarcerated father are Black children.<ref name="gjyc"/> This is data that has been published in scholarly and peer-reviewed articles, but as the article "Children of Color and Parental Incarceration: Implications for Research, Theory, and Practice" states, "these data among racial minorities must be carefully interpreted because higher numbers may be a reflection of larger societal issues (such as relative degree of involvement in crime, disparate law enforcement practices, sentencing parole policies and practices and biased decision making... rather than a problem among certain groups."<ref name="gjyc"/>
==Barriers to reentry to society== Of women in US state prisons, 44% do not have a high school diploma or equivalent ([[GED]]).<ref name="Sentencing Project" /> As they reenter their communities, former inmates confront sparse job opportunities, limited options for stable and affordable housing, denials of public assistance, as well as the challenge of re-establishing relationships with family and friends.<ref>{{cite book|last=Talvi|first=Silja|title=Women Behind Bars: The Crisis of Women in the U.S. Prison System|year=2007|publisher=Seal Press|location=Emeryville|pages=69}}</ref> However, relationships, in particular among family, provide an extremely beneficial support system for prisoners returning home upon their release. Difficulties with employment, housing, and ostracism can decrease successful transitions and lead to [[Recidivism|a cycle in and out of prison]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
Some concerns that are faced by policy-makers and correction officials about women re-entering into the community after prison are motherhood and the struggle with substance abuse and mental health issues.
Scholars have found that women face negative perceptions such as being seen as inadequate and unable to provide a stable, loving home for their children when they are transitioning back from prison into motherhood. This separation of children from their mothers is harmful to both the child and mother and this is the main reason for stress inside of women prisons. For many women getting out of prison, the only aspect of life they consider to be motivating and hopeful is resuming motherhood and connecting with their children again. Without their children, many see no reason to stay away from drugs or prostitution. Women in these circumstances are understood to have a better life if they are offered proper nutritional and medical care so they could lead a more stable lifestyle.<ref name="The Urban Institute Press">{{cite book|last1=Travis|first1=Jeremy|title=Prisoners Once Removed: The Impact of Incarceration and Reentry of Children, Families, and Communities|date=2003|publisher=The Urban Institute Press|pages=76–103}}</ref>
The struggle of addiction whether it be alcohol or drug abuse along with mental health issues are considered the three major factors that influence the success of women's transition back into the community. Women tend to take out their anger on themselves and in a self-mutilating or abusive way. Mood disorders, such as depression or anxiety, are seen to be more common among women than men. A study from 1990 found that 19 percent of women who suffer from depression, 31 percent of women who suffer from phobic disorders, and 7 percent of women that suffer from panic disorder also struggled with alcohol abuse. Women who have been released from prison face the struggle against addiction and could end up losing their children because of it.<ref name="The Urban Institute Press"/>
In order for women to successfully transition back into society, they must begin this preparation process at the beginning of their sentence. Although this is recommended, inmates tend to not have any preparation before being placed back into the community. All of the released women have tasks they must complete in order to re-establish a place in society and in order to stay out of trouble. These are things such as, follow parole regulations, provide health care for themselves and/or their families, become financially stable, obtain employment, and find a safe place to live, all while possibly battling addiction. Without support from the community, women under these circumstances tend to fall back into drugs or criminal activity.<ref name="The Urban Institute Press"/>
==Women prison organizations== There are programs that have been established to help women after they are released from prison.<ref name=jksp>{{cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Kristine A.|author2=Shannon M. Lynch|title=Predictors of maladaptive coping in incarcerated women who are survivors of childhood sexual abuse|journal=Family Violence|date=19 March 2014|volume=28|issue=1}}</ref>
System organizations that are used to help women's reentry into the community consist of mental health, alcohol and drug programs, programs to help survivors and sexual violence, family services, food shelters, financial help programs, employment services, child care services, and community service clubs.
A continuity-of-care approach is taken when forming these programs for women. This is the providing of treatment, recovery, and support services throughout the entire process of reentry for women.
Programs: * Helping Women Recover: Program designed for treating substance abuse. This focuses on issues such as self-esteem, parenting, relationships, and spirituality. The program addresses these issues using discussion, activities, and exercises. * Beyond Trauma: A Healing Journey for Women: This is 11 sessions long and teaches women what trauma is, and how it affects their thoughts and feelings as well as their behavior and relationships. The work is done on coping skills using exercises and videos. * The Sanctuary Model: This program addresses the issues of mental health, trauma, and substance abuse. This focuses on safety and grieving to build individual empowerment. * Seeking Safety: Program for women that have substance dependence and also PTSD. This focuses on five key elements: safety, treatment of PTSD and substance abuse, ideals, behavioral and interpersonal therapies, and therapist processes. * The Addiction and Trauma Recovery Integration Model (ATRIUM): psycho-educational 12-week-long program. This is designed to intervene on levels of the body, mind and spirit. * The Trauma Recovery and Empowerment Model (TREM): psycho-educational group that includes survival empowerment, self-soothing, and problem solving. This last 33 sessions over nine months.
These programs help women to not feel depressed or overwhelmed by the community once they are allowed to reenter them. There are two agencies that help these women as well, more well known as a settlement house.
* Our Place: This is located in Washington D.C. and focuses mainly on family reunification. This helps women reunite with family, and find housing and employment. This program helps women find the help needed whether it be mental help or substance abuse treatment. * The Refugee Model: The Catholic Church works to assist the parolees and support their transitioning. This helps to make the women feel like someone is looking after them and encouraging them as they work to reenter the community. System organizations that are used to help women's reentry into the community consist of mental health, alcohol and drug programs, programs to help survivors and sexual violence, family services, food shelters, financial help programs, employment services, child care services, and community service clubs.
A continuity-of-care approach is taken when forming these programs for women. This is the providing of treatment, recovery, and support services throughout the entire process of reentry for women.<ref name="The Urban Institute Press"/>
== Media portrayal == Despite all the things that incarcerated women endure prior to, during, and after their imprisonment, people often have a certain mindset regarding who they are. This is as a result of the inaccuracy the media uses to portray women who are detained; perpetuating the idea that there is nothing more to them than violence and sexual tension. The media's tendency to highlight the aspects of prison life that they deem suitable or entertaining for viewers really serves to belittle and shed attention away from the real issues that incarceration has on the women living their 'truth'. The way that these women are portrayed in the media is crucial to our understanding of their struggles and our ability to empathize with the traumatic experience that is serving time in prison. Instead, they are portrayed with a 'babes behind bars' theme.<ref name=":12">{{cite journal | last1 = Cecil | first1 = Dawn K | year = 2007 | title = Looking beyond caged heat: Media images of women in prison | url = | journal = Feminist Criminology | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 304–326 | doi=10.1177/1557085107306142}}</ref>
Films such as ''[[The Big Doll House]]'' (1971), ''[[The Big Bird Cage]]'' (1972) and ''[[Caged Heat]]'' (1974) are examples of movies that depict these women as sex-crazed and distort our knowledge from the more universal and serious issues that come with being incarcerated. Because we live in a patriarchal society, women are viewed as objects for intercourse, and their issues are not taken as severely as we would that of males.
{{quote|Very little factual representation is contained in these films. It is Hollywood, after all; they do not necessarily seek to educate—instead they aim to titillate:
These tales of vulnerable young things navigating a harsh prison are largely vehicles for money shot–style images that are the films' raison d'être: a roomful of women being hosed down by their sadistic warden as punishment (1971's Big Doll House) . . . or a young reform-school inmate gang-raped with a plunger by her roommates (1974's Born Innocent)".<ref name=":12" />}}

Country Club planning to host 2023 U.S. Open |date=August 28, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2017}} | rating1 = 75.7 | slope1 = 143{{cite web|url=https://ncrdb.usga.org/NCRDB/courseTeeInfo.aspx?CourseID=5650 |publisher=USGA |title=Course Rating and Slope Database™ - Los Angeles Country Club - North Course |accessdate=February 19, 2017}} | record1 = | course2 = South Course | designer2 = | par2 = 70 | length2 = | rating2 = 71.1 | slope2 = 129{{cite web|url=https://ncrdb.usga.org/NCRDB/courseTeeInfo.aspx?CourseID=5651 |publisher=USGA |title=Course Rating and Slope Database™ - Los Angeles Country Club - South Course |accessdate=February 19, 2017}} | record2 = }} The '''Los Angeles Country Club''' is a golf and [[country club]] in the [[Western United States]], located in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. ==History== In the fall of 1897, a group of Los Angeles residents organized the '''Los Angeles Golf Club,''' and a {{convert|16|acre|adj=on}} lot was leased at the corner of Pico and Alvarado streets (now part of the [[Alvarado Terrace Historic District]]) for a nine-hole [[golf course]]. Called "The Windmill Links," the course was named for a makeshift [[Country club|clubhouse]] crafted from the bottom of an abandoned [[windmill]]. Through the middle of 1898, this site served as the club's home until the course became too crowded. The club was removed to [[Pico-Union, Los Angeles|Pico Heights]], at Hobart and 16th streets. The new home was named "The Convent Links" for its location behind a [[convent]] near [[Angelus-Rosedale Cemetery|Rosedale Cemetery]]. Again, nine holes were laid out for play, but by the spring of 1899, this course and clubhouse had also become too restricted for play. The search committee for a new site, consisting of the club founders [[Joseph Francis Sartori|Joe Sartori]] and Ed Tufts, found the club's new home just {{convert|0.2|mi|m|-2}} west, on the northeast corner of Pico and Western. The [[country club|clubhouse]] was transported intact to a new site in Beverly Hills, and it was expanded there. The club also laid out an 18-hole course. The club reopened on May 30, 1911. It now has 36 holes of golf and tennis courts. The original golf course was laid out by Joe Sartori, Ed Tufts, [[Norman Macbeth]], and Charles Orr. Later, the courses were redesigned by [[William Herbert Fowler|Herbert Fowler]] and [[George C. Thomas, Jr.]], and again by Thomas with William P. Bell in 1927-28. In 1996 and 1997 an extensive renovation of the north and south courses was completed. In February 2010, an [https://www.thelacc.org/files/NorthCourse_Commemorative_Edition.pdf extensive restoration] of the North Course by Gil Hanse and Thomas biographer Geoff Shackelford took place to return the course to [[George C. Thomas, Jr.]]'s design from 1921. The course reopened in October 2010. The north course hosted the first [[Los Angeles Open]] {{Time ago|1926}} in 1926, and it returned four times:{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-us-open-la-20150722-story.html|title=L.A. Country Club to host 2023 U.S. Open |work=Los Angeles Times |last=Wharton |first=David |date=July 22, 2015 |accessdate=February 19, 2017}} 1934, 1935,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=G9NXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=__QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7131%2C3711813 |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Ghezzi takes golf title from Revolta |date=January 16, 1935 |page=13}} 1936, and 1940.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BcxYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lugDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5755%2C5875328 |work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |agency=Associated Press |last=Myers |first=Robert |title=Lawson Little wins Los Angeles Open |date=January 9, 1940 |page=6}} {{cn|date=July 2015}} The most recent in 1940, won by [[Lawson Little]], was plagued by heavy rains. On July 22, 2015, the [[United States Golf Association]] announced that Los Angeles Country Club was selected to host the 123rd [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] in 2023. == Tournament history == *[[Los Angeles Open]] {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" !Year !Player !Country !Score !To par !Margin

{{Infobox Former Country |native_name = Masmughan-e Damavand |conventional_long_name = Masmughans of Damavand |common_name = Tabaristan |continent = Asia |region = Middle East |country = Iran |era = [[Middle Ages]] |status = |government_type = Monarchy |year_start = 651 |year_end = 760 |event_start = [[Muslim conquest of Persia]] |date_start = |event1 = |date_event1 = |event2 = |date_event2 = |event_end = [[Abbasid]] conquest |date_end = |p1 = Sassanid Empire |flag_p1 = Derafsh Kaviani.png |s1 = Abbasid Caliphate |flag_s1 = black flag.svg |image_flag = |flag_type = |flag = |image_coat = |symbol_type = |symbol = |image_map = |image_map_caption = Domains of the Masmughans of Damavand |capital = [[Damavand, Iran|Damavand]] |common_languages = [[Middle Persian]], [[Caspian languages]] |religion = [[Zoroastrianism]] |currency = |title_leader = [[Masmughan]] |leader1 = [[Mardanshah of Damavand]] <small>(first)</small> |year_leader1 = |leader2 = |year_leader2 = }} {{History of Iran}} The '''Masmughans of Damavand''' ([[Middle Persian]]: Masmughan-i Dumbawand, [[Persian language|New Persian]]: مس مغان دماوند, meaning ''Great Magians of Damavand'') were a local dynasty, which ruled [[Mount Damavand|Damavand]] and its surrounding areas from ca. 651 to 760. The founder of the dynasty was a [[House of Karen|Karenid]]<ref>Pourshariati (2008), pp. 253</ref> named [[Mardanshah of Damavand]].
== History == The Masmughans of Damavand are first mentioned by [[Al-Tabari]], where the [[Masmughan]] [[Mardanshah of Damavand]] reportedly aided the [[House of Mihran|Mihranid]] Siyavakhsh at [[Ray, Iran|Ray]] against the Arabs. The forces of Siyavakhsh and Mardanshah, were, however, defeated. Mardanshah then made peace with the Arabs in return for an annual tribute.<ref>"Maṣmug̲h̲an." Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition. Edited by: P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs. Brill Online, 2013. Reference. 30 November 2013 <http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/masmughan-COM_0702></ref>
In 748/749, [[Abu Muslim]] sought to subdue the Masmughan but his general Musa ibn Kab was ambushed by the local forces who enjoyed the advantage of the terrain, which forced him to return to [[Ray, Iran|Ray]]. In 758/759 due to disputes between Abarwiz and his brother, who is simply called ''Masmughan'' in Arabic sources, Abarwiz then went over to the [[Caliph]] [[Al-Mansur]] who gave him a pension. In some Arabic sources Abarwiz is called Al-Masmughan Malik (''[[malik]] of the [[Masmughan]]s''), and is known for his bravery.
In 760, Masmughan, the brother of Abarwiz, was at war against his father-in-law, the [[Dabuyid]] [[ispahbadh]] [[Khurshid of Tabaristan|Khurshid]], but when he heard about the Abbasid expedition to [[Tabaristan]], he made peace with the latter. The Arabs then defeated the [[ispahbadh]] and the Masmughan, who was captured along with his daughters Bakhtariya and Shakla. One of these daughters became the wife of [[Al-Mahdi]].

{{hatnote|'Door god' redirects here. For the Roman god of doors, see [[Janus]].}} {{chinese |pic=File:頂泰山巖001門神.jpg |piccap=A Taiwanese menshen |t={{linktext|門神}} |s={{linktext|门神}} |p=ménshén |l={{nowrap|gate god(s)}} }} {{chinese |title=Martial{{nbsp}}Door{{nbsp}}Gods |t={{linktext|武|門神}} |s={{linktext|武|门神}} |p=wuménshén |l={{nowrap|military gate god(s)}} }} {{chinese |title=Civil{{nbsp}}Door{{nbsp}}Gods |t={{linktext|文|門神}} |s={{linktext|文|门神}} |p=wenménshén |l={{nowrap|literary gate god(s)}} }} {{Chinese folk religion}} '''Menshen''' or '''door gods'''{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} are divine guardians of doors and gates in [[Chinese folk religion]]s, used to protect against evil influences or to encourage the entrance of positive ones. They began as the divine pair [[Shenshu (deity)|Shenshu]] ({{zh|神荼}}) and [[Yulü]] ({{zh|鬱壘}}) under the [[Han dynasty|Han]], but the [[apotheosis|deified]] generals [[Qin Shubao]] ({{zh|秦叔寶}}) and [[Yuchi Gong]] ({{zh|尉迟恭}}) have been more popular since the [[Tang dynasty|Tang]]. In cases where a door god is affixed to a single door, [[Wei Zheng]] or [[Zhong Kui]] is commonly used. ==History== The gates and doors of [[Chinese architecture|Chinese house]]s have long received special ritual attention.{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} Sacrifices to a door spirit are recorded as early as the ''[[Book of Rites]]''.{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}}{{citation |editor-last=Legge |date=1885 |title=Book of Rites, ''Vol. II'' |p=207 }}. By the [[Han dynasty|Han]], this spirit had become the two gods [[Shenshu (deity)|Shenshu]] and [[Yulü]], whose names or images were painted into [[peachwood]] and attached to doors.{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} The [[Emperor Taizong of Tang|Great Ancestor]] of the [[Tang dynasty|Tang]] ("Emperor Taizong") ordered portraits of his generals [[Qin Shubao]] and [[Yuchi Gong]] to be affixed to gates.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} They eventually [[apotheosis|came to be considered divine protectors]], replacing Shentu and Yulü and remaining the most common door gods to the present day.{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} Qin and Yuchi, along with various other [[apotheosis|deified]] military leaders, make up a class of {{nowrap|'''martial door gods'''}} intended to ward off evil spirits and bad influences. A separate group of scholars make up a class of {{nowrap|'''civil door gods'''}} intended to attract blessings and good fortune.{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} Some deities are also thought to have guardians who serve a similar role at their temples, such as [[Lin Moniang|Mazu]]'s companions [[Qianliyan]] and [[Shunfeng'er]]. ==Legends== The 10th chapter of the [[Four Classic Novels|Chinese novel]] ''[[Journey to the West]]'' includes an account of the origin of door gods. In it, the [[Dragon King]] of the [[Jing River]] disguised himself as a human to outsmart the fortune teller Yuan Shoucheng. Since he was able to control the weather, he made a bet with Yuan about [[Chang'an]]'s forecast for the next day. He was nonplussed, however, when he received an order from the [[Jade Emperor]] telling him to give the city precisely the weather Yuan had predicted. The Dragon King preferred to win the bet and disregarded the order, going to Yuan to gloat the next day. Yuan remained calm and revealed that he had known the Dragon King's identity all along. Moreover, since the dragon had been so arrogant as to disregard an order from the Jade Emperor, his doom would be short in coming. The dragon was shocked to see his disobedience known and immediately pleaded with Yuan to save him. Yuan let him know that the Jade Emperor would send [[Wei Zheng]]—a senior minister from the court of the [[Emperor Taizong of Tang|Great Ancestor]] of the [[Tang dynasty|Tang]] ("Emperor Taizong")—to execute him at noon the following day. He told him his best course of action was to ask Taizong for help and, taking pity on the Dragon King, the emperor agreed to save him. In order to do so, the emperor summoned Wei Zheng to play [[go (game)|go]] with him in the morning. He endeavored to keep Wei from leaving until after noon, preventing him from carrying out the Jade Emperor's order, and was delighted when Wei grew so tired with the long game that he fell asleep. A little while later, however, the Great Ancestor was told that a dragon's head had fallen from the sky. Wei awoke and told him that his spirit had left his body during his nap and gone to [[Tian|Heaven]] to carry out the Jade Emperor's order. The annoyed spirit of the Dragon King then haunted the Great Ancestor each night until his generals [[Qin Shubao]] and [[Yuchi Gong]] volunteered to stand guard at his door. The emperor enjoyed his peaceful sleep but did not want to continue bothering his two generals. In their place, he had artists paint their portraits and paste them to the doors. This was then copied by his subjects.{{citation |title=The Journey to the West |at=Ch. 10 |url=http://down02.putclub.com/virtual/backup/update/Download/Literature/The_Journey_To_The_West_Wu_Cheng_en.pdf |last=Wu |first=Cheng'en |authormask=[[Wu Cheng'en]] }}. ==Architecture== In modern use, door gods are usually printed images which are pasted to paired doors. They are usually replaced every [[Chinese New Year]].{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} Occasionally, they are sculpted in relief or placed as statues to either side of a door. The figures should face each other; it is considered bad luck to place them back to back.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} ==Worship== In ancient China, there was a ritual for a sacrifice to the door spirit of a wealthy home recorded in the ''[[Book of Rites]]''. In modern China, door gods do not make up a formal element of [[Taoism in China|Taoism]] and are included as traditional decorations or as nods to [[Chinese folk religion|popular superstition]].{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=744}} There are, however, some deities worshipped for other reasons—including the [[Azure Dragon]],{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=745}} the [[White Tiger (China)|White Tiger]],{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=745}} and [[Lin Moniang|Mazu]]'s companions [[Qianliyan]] and [[Shunfeng'er]]—who also serve as door gods at Taoist temples.{{sfnp|Clart|2008|p=745}} {{clear}} ==List== The following persons, some of whom are mythological figures, are known to have been worshipped as door gods. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=2 | Names ! rowspan=2 | Description |- ! Civil - Project Gutenberg eText 15250.jpg | A [[wen and wu|civil]] door god,{{citation |title=Myths and Legends of China |date=1922 |first=E.T.C. |last=Werner }}. gathering good influences |File:The Door-gods, Civil and Military 1.jpg | A [[wen and wu|martial]] door god, protecting against bad influences }} ==See also== * [[Feng shui]], which also employs shield walls, [[talisman]]s, [[mirror]]s, and [[yin-yang]] symbols to protect doorways * [[Chinese gods and immortals]] * [[Dvarapala]] * [[Gate guardian]] * [[Imperial guardian lions]] ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{citation |url=https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=R3Sp6TfzhpIC&printsec=frontcover |title=The Encyclopedia of Taoism, ''Vol. II'' |date=2008 |publisher=Routledge |location=Abingdon |contribution-url=https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=R3Sp6TfzhpIC&pg=PA744 |pp=[https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=R3Sp6TfzhpIC&pg=PA744 744–5] |last=Clart |first=Philip |contribution=Menshen }}. * {{citation |last=Tang |first=Rose |contribution-url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/stdn/std/Front_Page/FI24Aa04.html |contribution=Twilight of the Door Gods |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/ |title=The Standard |location=Hong Kong }}. ==External links== *{{Commons-inline|Category:Menshen|Menshen}} [[Category:Taoism]] [[Category:Chinese architecture]] [[Category:Chinese architectural history]] [[Category:Chinese culture]] [[Category:Chinese gods]] [[Category:Chinese mythology]]

{{Orphan|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Michael Strickland | image = | caption = | birth_name = Michael Aaron Strickland | birth_date = | birth_place = | criminal_charge = 2017: Unlawful use of weapon (10 counts), menacing (10 counts), second-degree disorderly misconduct (1 count).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2017/02/guilty_man_who_pulled_gun_out.html |title=Guilty: Man who pulled gun out at 'Don't Shoot PDX' protest}}</ref> }}
'''Michael Strickland''' is a conservative blogger and for the ''Progressives Today'' blog and shares video on his [[YouTube]] channel called "LaughingAtLiberals".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/LaughingAtLiberals/|title=LaughingAtLiberals|website=YouTube|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref>
==Blogging== Strickland contributes blog posts to the website Progressives Today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.progressivestoday.com/author/michael-strickland/|title=Michael Strickland, Author at Progressives Today|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> {{As of|October 2016}}, Strickland's YouTube channel, LaughingAtLiberals, has over 20,000 subscribers.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/user/LaughingAtLiberals LaughingAtLiberals YouTube .</ref>
==Whiteness History Month== At [[Portland Community College]] (PCC)'s Whiteness History Month in April 2016, Strickland attended several events to produce film for his YouTube channel LaughingAtLiberals. A PCC spokeswoman said he was routinely "pushing buttons" and posting heavily edited videos about the events.<ref name="theen13">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/education/index.ssf/2016/07/portland_colleges_ban_man_char.html|title=Portland colleges ban man charged with waving gun at Don't Shoot PDX march|last=Theen|first=Andrew|date=13 July 2016|work=[[OregonLive.com]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref>
== Race and Sexual Orientation Based Harassment == Law enforcement say that Strickland has a past police report alleging "possibly race-based threats" against an attendee at a Portland vigil for the victims of last month's nightclub shooting in Orlando, Florida.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2016/07/man_accused_of_pulling_gun_on.html|title=Man accused of pulling gun on Portland protesters was armed with multiple magazines of ammo, prosecutor says|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref> Strickland, who also participated in Portland State University's PSU for Trump group, was alleged to have participated in online harassment campaigns against lesbian and transgender students and also filmed and mocked students and activists along with PSU for Trump members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whoismichaelstrickland.com/|title=Michael Strickland {{!}} Michael Strickland of Portland is a white supremacist|website=whoismichaelstrickland.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=LaughingAtLiberals|title=Raw, Uncut: Wackjob Students Takeover PSU Board Meeting|date=2016-06-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=He1lNosT6-E|accessdate=2017-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=LaughingAtLiberals|title=Triggliots Lose Their Minds At Trump Event|date=2016-06-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiADgGSGHiM|accessdate=2017-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thinkprogress.org/how-students-for-trump-terrorized-portland-state-university-88396c06c743/|title=How ‘Students for Trump’ terrorized Portland State University|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Don't Shoot Portland rally gun incident== At a [[Black Lives Matter]] rally in Portland, Oregon, on 7 July 2016, Strickland pulled a [[Glock#9×19mm Parabellum|Glock 26]] pistol and pointed it at protesters, including an undercover police officer. Portland police reported that Strickland's pistol was equipped with "an extremely large magazine" (over 120 rounds in multiple magazines) and had a round in the chamber.<ref name="koin13">{{cite news|url=http://koin.com/2017/02/12/man-who-pulled-gun-on-crowd-guilty/|title=Man who pulled gun on crowd guilty|last=Weisberg|first=Brent|date=12 February 2017|work=[[KOIN]]|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref><ref name="pdxtribune07">{{cite news|url=http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/314304-193157-man-with-gun-arrested-at-downtown-rally-protesting-recent-police-shootings|title=Gun arrest mars peaceful Don't Shoot Portland rally|date=7 July 2016|work=[[Portland Tribune]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> The police also reported Strickland was carrying five extra magazines for the pistol, all loaded.<ref name="pdxtribune07" /><ref name="opb08">{{cite news|url=http://www.opb.org/news/article/gun-pulled-black-lives-matter-portland-charges-michael-strickland/|title=Man Accused Of Pulling Gun At Portland Black Lives Matter Protest Appears In Court | last=Templeton|first=Amelia|date=8 July 2016|work=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> Strickland claims he was surrounded by several [[Anarchy|anarchist]] protesters who pushed and shoved him, and that he feared for his life.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kptv.com/story/32398549/man-who-displayed-gun-at-downtown-portland-protest-arrested|title=Man who displayed gun at downtown Portland protest arrested|date=7 July 2016|work=[[KPTV]] Fox 12|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="olive_07" />
Portland's police chief, Mike Marshman, said Strickland's actions at the rally were "fully unacceptable", stating, "I'm very, very proud of the members of the Police Bureau who cautiously and safely enabled the protest to continue on. That's how it should be. To the men and women of the Police Bureau, please continue to do what you do."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2016/07/portland_mayor_police_chief_st.html | title=Portland mayor, police chief stand with faith leaders to deplore recent violence | last=Bernstein|first=Maxine|date=8 July 2016|work=[[OregonLive.com]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref>
Portland police arrested Strickland at the scene, charging him with [[menacing]] and [[disorderly conduct]], both misdemeanors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://katu.com/news/local/dozens-gather-for-blacklivesmatter-protest-in-portland|title=Dozens gather for #BlackLivesMatter protest in Portland|date=7 July 2016|work=[[KATU]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> Law enforcement officials then processed Strickland through the Multnomah County Detention Center and released Strickland on his own recognizance.<ref name="olive_07">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2016/07/dont_shoot_pdx_protesting_poli.html|title=Man pulls gun at Don't Shoot PDX protesting US police shootings|last=Ryan|first=Jim|date=7 July 2016|work=[[OregonLive.com]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> The next day the state added two additional charges of unlawful use of a firearm, a class C felony.<ref name="fontana_08">{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2016/07/man_who_pulled_gun_at_dont_sho.html#incart_2box |title=Man accused of pulling gun at Don't Shoot PDX rally released from jail|last=Fontana|first=Francesca|date=19 July 2016|work=[[OregonLive.com]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> At Strickland's arraignment, the judge set [[bail]] at $250,000, with Strickland being released after posting the required bail on July 18. A [[Multnomah County, Oregon|Multnomah County]] district attorney sought the high bail amount partly based on alleged race-based threats, including harassing texts and phone calls, reportedly made by Strickland at a previous [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]] vigil.<ref name="opb08" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2016/07/man_accused_of_pulling_gun_on.html|title=Man accused of pulling gun on Portland protesters was armed with multiple magazines of ammo, prosecutor says|last=Bernstein|first=Maxine|date=8 July 2016|work=[[OregonLive.com]]|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref>
In response to the incident and based on his activities on campuses, [[Portland State University]] banned Strickland from its campus for two years, and Portland Community College indefinitely banned Strickland from its campus.<ref name="theen13" />
On February 10, 2017, Strickland was found guilty of all 21 counts: 10 counts of unlawful use of a weapon, 10 counts of menacing, and one count of disorderly conduct. He was sentenced to 40 days in jail, 240 hours of community service, banned from taking video of people or events for at least 2017, and is also banned from owning guns.<ref>http://www.kxl.com/no-prison-journalist-displays-gun-protest/</ref><ref>http://katu.com/news/local/man-who-pointed-pistol-at-protesters-banned-from-owning-guns</ref> During the hearing the court discussed finding in a pre-sentence investigation that Strickland had Autistic tendencies or Aspergers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kxl.com/no-prison-journalist-displays-gun-protest/|title=No Prison For Journalist Who Displays Gun During A Protest - KXL|date=2017-05-03|work=KXL|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Mike BlueHair|title=Man pulls gun on crowd of Portland protesters|date=2016-07-08|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FH7aTp8DsVI&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-08-31}}</ref>

{{expand language|topic=|langcode=ko|otherarticle=밀양지역 고교생의 여중생 집단 성폭행 사건|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul=밀양지역 여중생 집단 강간 사건 |hanja=密陽地域女中生集團性暴行事件 |rr=Miryang-jiyeok yeojungsaeng jipdan ganggan sageon |mr=Miryang-jiyŏk yŏjungsaeng chiptan kanggan sagŏn }} The '''Miryang gang rape''', known in [[South Korea]] as the '''Miryang middle school girls rape incident''', was a criminal incident that occurred in [[Miryang]], South Korea in 2004. At least 41 male high school students [[gang rape]]d several middle school and high school girls over the course of 11 months.<ref name="joong2008" /> The case provoked controversy due to police mistreatment of the victims and lenient handling of the offenders.<ref name="rahn2004" />
==Assaults== The victims lived in [[Ulsan]] and [[Changwon]], while the perpetrators were from Miryang and Changwon.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://legacy.www.hani.co.kr/section-005000000/2004/12/005000000200412091732001.html | title = 집단성폭행 가해자 41명외 ‘70여명’ 더 있다 | work = The Hankyoreh | year = 2004 | language = Korean | accessdate = 26 March 2015}}</ref> The perpetrators were initially believed to be members of a high school [[gang]],<ref name="joong2004" /> but little evidence for this was found.<ref name="jeong">{{cite news|author=Jeong, Jae-Rak |date=12 December 2004 |title=Police Once Again Hurt Victimized Middle School Girls |work=The Dong-a Ilbo |url=http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2004121329028 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111125022216/http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2004121329028 |archivedate=November 25, 2011 }}</ref> They met the first 14-year-old victim over the phone. When she visited them, she was sexually assaulted, with the scene being filmed for blackmail.<ref name="rahn2004" /> According to police, she was raped up to 10 times by 3 to 24 high school boys in each occurrence,<ref name="joong2004">{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2503972|title=Outrage sparked by serial rape case|work=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=12 December 2004|accessdate=30 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103094710/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2503972|archivedate=3 November 2012|df=}}</ref> with at least 41 boys being involved over 11 months.<ref name="joong2008" /> The girl was ordered to bring her 13-year-old sister and 16-year-old cousin to Miryang,<ref name="joong2004" /> where the cousin was raped.<ref name="rahn2004" /> The original police report stated that the younger sister was sexually assaulted as well, but it may only have been a physical assault.<ref name="jeong" /> The boys were also accused of raping two other girls.<ref name="rahn2004">{{cite news|author=Rahn, Kim |date=12 December 2004 |title=Sexual Assault Case Provokes Uproar |work=The Korea Times |accessdate=27 March 2015 |url=http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/200412/kt2004121217002910230.htm |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050419130038/http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/200412/kt2004121217002910230.htm |archivedate=April 19, 2005 }}</ref> They allegedly extorted money from their victims.<ref name="joo2005" />
==Aftermath== After the sisters' aunt reported the rapes to the police,<ref name="joong2008" /> three of the boys were arrested. Following protests from the victims and public, another nine students were arrested, and 29 booked without detention.<ref name="rahn2004" /> Family members of the perpetrators threatened the victims,<ref name="rahn2004" /> warning them that they should "watch out from now on for reporting our sons to police."<ref name="joong2004" /> In a television interview, a parent of one of the offenders stated, "Why should we feel sorry for the victim's family? Why don't you consider our suffering? Who can resist temptation when girls are trying to seduce boys? They should have taught their daughters how to behave in order to avoid this kind of accident."<ref name="joo2005" /> One girl reportedly quit school after repeated visits and verbal attacks from the offenders' parents.<ref>{{cite news | author = Lee, Claire | date = 5 March 2015 | title = Korea educates families of juvenile sex offenders | work = The Korea Herald | url = http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150305001225}}</ref>
A controversy erupted over allegations that the police had mistreated the victims, culminating in a [[candlelight vigil]] by 150 protesters.<ref name="rahn2004" /> The victims had asked to be questioned by a female police officer, but their request was ignored.<ref name="rahn2004" /> One police officer allegedly said to the victims, "Did you try to entice the guys? You ruined the reputation of Miryang. The boys who would lead the city were all arrested. What are you going to do? [...] I am afraid that my daughter will be like you."<ref name="ilbo">{{cite news | author = Park Sung-woo JoongAng Ilbo | date = 18 August 2007 | title = Damages ordered paid in Milyang assault case | work = Korea JoongAng Daily | accessdate = 27 March 2015 | url = http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2879431}}</ref> Police also leaked enough information to the media for the victims to be identified. Furthermore, they forced the victims to identify the suspects face-to-face, rather than through a [[one-way mirror]],<ref name="joong2008" /> with the officer asking the victim, "Did he insert [it] or not?"<ref name="joo2005" /> One of the victims had to be [[Psychiatric hospital|hospitalized]] for psychiatric treatment after these experiences.<ref name="joo2005" /> In August 2007, the Seoul High Court found the Miryang police officers guilty of negligence in protecting the victims, and ordered them to pay damages totaling 50 million [[Korean won|won]] to two of the victims and their family.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/nation_view.asp?newsIdx=8523&categoryCode=117 |title=Police Found Guilty of Insulting Rape Victims |date=17 August 2007 |accessdate=30 April 2012 |work=[[The Korea Times]] |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005181646/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/nation_view.asp?newsIdx=8523&categoryCode=117 |archivedate=October 5, 2011 }}</ref> The decision was upheld by the [[Supreme Court of South Korea]] in June 2008, which set the compensation at 70 million won.<ref name="joong2008">{{cite news | date = 17 July 2008 | title = Court orders state to pay for ID leak of rape victims | work = Korea JoongAng Daily | url = http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2891213}}</ref>
Prosecutors sent most of the accused to Juvenile Court or dropped charges. Ten others were formally accused of group sexual assault, with prosecutors asking for two to four years imprisonment with a three-year [[stay of execution]]. Citing the young age of the offenders and the fact that some had already been admitted to college or hired for jobs, the judges refused the charges against even these ten, instead sending them to Juvenile Court.<ref name="joo2005">{{cite journal | author = Joo-Hyun, C. | year = 2005 | title = Intersectionality revealed: Sexual politics in post-IMF Korea | journal = Korea Journal | volume = 45 | issue = 3 | pages = 107–110}}</ref> One factor in this decision was that the father of one of the victims formed an agreement with some of the offenders to plead for leniency after receiving a large sum of money. The father was an [[alcoholic]] who had divorced the victim's mother three years prior due to his [[domestic violence]], but retained parental rights over his daughter, and persuaded her to accept the agreement.<ref name="joo2005" /> Ultimately, only five suspects were sent to a [[juvenile detention center]], and none were convicted of criminal charges.<ref name="ilbo" /> In 2012, it emerged that the girlfriend of one of the perpetrators had become a police officer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20120409n22558|script-title=ko:밀양 성폭행 피해자 조롱한 여학생이 경찰이 됐다고?|trans-title=The female student who derided the victims of the sexual assaults in Miryang became a police officer... ?|language=Korean|publisher=[[Nate (web portal)|Nate]]|date=9 April 2012|accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.koreabang.com/2012/stories/friend-of-rapist-becomes-police-officer-netizens-disgusted.html | title = Friend of Rapist Becomes Police Officer, Netizens Disgusted | work = KoreaBang | author = Alenka | date = 15 April 2012}}</ref>
== See also == * ''[[Han Gong-ju]]'', a film inspired by these events
